job_title: Admissions Manager in Denver, CO
pros: Working at Ashford is similar to going high school. It's easy. You can go to work, sit at your desk, have conversations with people all day and build some great relationships with co-workers. Once you have proven that you have the chops to succeed as an Admissions Counselor, you can be promoted to manangement. At this level you will receive a tremendous opportunity to learn and develop both personally and professionally. The pay is a lot better as an Admissions Manager.
cons: The work/life balance of the Admissions Counselor is not too bad. However, they do ask you to work a lot of Saturdays. Once you are in management, you can say goodbye to any life you have outside of Ashford walls. You are a slave to them. If you don't commit everything to your position, you will suffer in your role. If you give everything to the position, your other relationships will be jeapordized. If you are married or in a serious relationship before you go into management, please make sure that they are fully aware that all your time will be devoted to Ashford (if you want to be successful). All in all, it's not terrible. Use it as a career move to get management experience. Be forewarned--most other companies/industries think that for-profit education is a joke. They do not respect what you will have learned or performed at Ashford.

job_title: Adjunct Faculty Online in Nashville, TN
pros:
They did train me how to teach online when I had no online experience. There are support people you can reach out to for help with anything.

There are opportunities to learn how to become a better educator with professional development webinars and conferences.
cons: I am not paid for the actual hours I work.  Per contract, they estimate you work 12 hrs a week, but I work double or even triple that.  You work everyday because there is a quick turnaround time  for a 5 weeks course. Assignments are due Thursday and Monday. Meanwhile you are posting the prior weeks discussion grades on the same Thursday , participating in the current weeks discussion and returning  major assignment grades by Sunday night. It is a lot of work, not to mention emailing students. The new LMS Canvas is a gem, but until you get comfortable with your course  material and schedule , you might be a little crazy town. I’m talking about late nights.....

review_title: Job for those who can't find work elsewhere
job_title: Student Advisor in San Diego, CA
pros: Decent pay and benefits, free continuing education (AA, BA, MA), really nice co-workers.
cons: In student facing positions you can expect your actions to be monitored every minute of the day.  Training facilitated by the Learning and Development team is pointless and a waste of company resources.  Critical thinking an innovation is not welcome in student facing departments- if you have any constructive feedback you will been seen as someone that is not a follower and may lose out on promotion opportunities. Management is young and inexperienced with little to no skills in how to develop employees. New ideas are presented by leadership and then you never hear about the initiatives again, so don't get excited about anything that sounds like a good thing.  Promotions tend to be granted to people who are "nice" and friends with the right people (but not always).  Technology internally is terrible and things never seem to work right.  Really poor communication between departments and no sense of urgency for those that are not student facing. It is not uncommon to hear employees talk about how much they dislike working their or are in fear of being fired.  The company recently downsized as it has been doing on and off for the past few years.  Really unstable work environment and accreditation issues.

review_title: Not about the student..only care about making money
job_title: Admissions Counselor in Denver, CO
pros: Decent pay, free degree, and benefits
cons:
Admissions Counselors are forced to sale a degree program! They will fire you if numbers aren't being met. At first it wasn't numbers so they fired you based on "commit to mission"... they come down on you if you aren't enrolling students. You have to enroll even if the student isn't ready. You are basically manipulating students into why they need to school..no difference from selling a car.. 
For example, they would want you to still enroll in spite of the student's situation.. sad..
BTW... in Denver they were hiring alot of people.. many people quit less than 6 mos.. if they are still there they are miserable. even managers.. due to stress.. . i know because alot of us hate.. because the job description and what they preach is the total opposite when you get on the "floor".. Yes. I said "floor" why would any education environment have a floor... Why? because it is a call center... like telemarketers... they also are going through accreditation issues with WASC.. they were denied due to student drop out..hardly any faculty.. this school bought a Christian College and with package came the HLC regional accrediation.. meaning they didn't earn it.. it was bought with the school because it was already accredited.. so this school is full of mess.. no employee should be treated like this..

cons: I personally think the company's parent company, Bridgepoint, is a sinking ship and sacrifices long-term health of the organization for short-term quarterly results. So glad I left and wish I had done so yeas earlier  I also feel they are reverting to old practices and philosophies that I believe led to their problems with accreditation in the first place. job_title: Admissions Counselor in San Diego, CA
pros:
Co-workers. I have met some amazing people here. I've also had the chance to help some folks with their education. All-in-all, unless you are a gifted sales person, you'll be out the door in a second profits dip. Working for this company will challenge your ability, that is for certain. I appreciated the opportunity to work hard and challenge myself. You will be put under stress and consistently-inconsistent circumstances. You will be held accountable for losing your students. If they have a stroke, computer fails, ice storm, they end up in jail, in the hospital, whatever...its your fault. This company is simply capitalism and need for profit in its purest form.  They micro-manage you. They have the ability to see EVERYTHING you do. You will answer for the time you spend on anything (unless you have a ton of students). Basically, if anything goes wrong with your business, you are screwed. 

Pretty good pay, good benefits. If you're successful at this job, you'll do well. 

Take the job if they offer. A glimpse into this industry is enlightening. If you're successful, then more power to you. :)
cons:
"What have you done for me lately" culture. You can work there and thrive for years. If you struggle too much, you're gone.

Divisional Management is relentlessly pushed to make managers perform, managers push  the counselors to perform (relentlessly). Managers tend to be good people, but they're constantly stressed out.

Turn over is HIGH. REALLY HIGH.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: Highly trained and professional staff dedicated to serving students as well as providing a quality education. In my experience staff and management are passionate about their service to the students. This is even more evident for those servicing the military. Advisers care about their students and many have walked in their shoes understanding the difficulties of the transition from military to civilian life. The entire organization as a whole from the president on down in my opinion is very dedicated to their mission and vision.
cons: The only real con I have is the issue of job instability which can create trust issues among employees. Ashford has had several layoffs over the past several years which contributes to job security issues as well as "survivor syndrome" for those left behind. Ultimately the need to lay off employees is really not their fault and has more to do with the instability of higher education on the "for profit" side of things. Similar "for profit" universities are going through similar pains.

job_title: Enrollment Advisor in Denver, CO
pros:
I've met a handful of nice people that are too talented to be working at Ashford University.
You get to ride the light rail...
cons:
I've met a large battery of unpleasant people, too. 
This is not a job for someone who believes an education is developing reading, writing, and critical thinking skills in addition to character and values. I took this job because I believe an education is an asset, and an educated populace is essential to social prosperity. I had serious doubts about working in a for-profit environment, however, where the real allegiance is to the shareholder and not the student, or employee, for that matter. If you thrive in a cut-throat sales environment, then you'll be fine here. However, I don't know many successful salespeople who would work for zero incentives, and there are none, other than keeping your job. Remember, you're only as good as your next "start".
Internal communications are ABYSMAL, and students suffer from the lack of interdepartmental continuity, most likely as the staff is too "green" to provide quality assistance. At Ashford University the attrition rate is alarming, and only 25% of Enrollment Services Advisors last longer than 6 months. I'm not sure if the same pace applies to Student Services, Financial Aid, etc, but I would suspect as much. Anyway, Ashford is an administrative nightmare. 
Benefits aren't fantastic. Could be worse. 
And....management. I define "management" and "leadership" differently, and the "management" at Ashford is woefully lacking in leadership skills, emotional intelligence, class, professionalism, and experience. But to their credit, they spend all day fighting fires on a sinking ship...
Overtime is mandatory when the division isn't making it's quota, which makes no sense in terms of overhead.

job_title: Student Advisor in San Diego, CA
pros: The people you work with is all you have on a day to day basis. Benefits are unbelievable (full benefits). Typically you can choose when you come in and when you leave work as well.
cons: Management is quite incompetent. People are given raises in regards to how well they can drink the cool aid (they tend to be kindergarten/preschool teachers and treat their employees as such). In my opinion movement and advancement is stagnant due to stocks plummeting and potential accreditation issues. They have since took all employees freedoms away and the workplace is an unhappy one. People tend to gossip a lot and I can not reiterate how incompetent management truly is. Many people on the floor who came from previous jobs e.g. enterprise rent a car had more experience than the majority of the current managers. In my opinion the focal point was not to truly help students more of how to retain them even if it was not fitting to make a profit. The only reason I am giving the work/life balance 3 stars is due to the stresses of the environment and the job, the hours are great and work well for you but this job does come home with you. I had numerous panic attacks while on the job. I have left and found new work and get calls from people begging for help while expressing misery in their current situation with Ashford.

job_title: Graduate Admissions Counselor in San Diego, CA
pros:
Loved the people and made many friends.  Loved my students and believed I was helping them. They invested in sales training. Team /company lunches.  Team building events. As much overtime as you wanted. No cap on earning potential. Earned my MA degree at no cost.
If your coachable you will make it. Trainers were great and approachable. I think the passion, vision and many peoples heart was there. Professors were great many employees were super intelligent, and hard working we all cared. And for us that were there a long time we wanted to make a change in the lives of our students.
cons:
It was ran like a Business. You must meet your matrics..Very high turnover of peers and management. it’s a numbers game. I rode through each and every storm not sure I would have a job afterwards. 
Top top leadership or greed or to meet investors demands we grew so fast! That stress trickled down through to admissions that it poisoned management to scare tactics to make your numbers and if not huge company laid offs over the years. so so sad they lost a lot of talented people who really believed in the company’s core values. 
No idea how it is now for matrics, advancement or what the company culture is like ext. good luck!

job_title: Student Advisor in Denver, CO
pros: On a local level, culture is fantastic. Everyone from local directors, managers, and Advisors seem genuinely concerned about one another's well being and success. This  is why I gave Ashford 2 stars.
cons: Ashford's upper echelons only seem concerned about the bottom line: money. This affects virtually every component of the company. Transparency from the top down is non existent. One blunder after another means daily responsibilities are constantly changing to adapt. Instead of taking a preventative approach regarding enrollment and retention, the majority of efforts are spent reacting to catastrophes, big and small. This reactivity enables many students (not all) to be needy and dependent.  There is little to no opportunity for growth. Consistently going above and beyond is barely rewarded or even recognized.  And unfortunately, initiatives to improve/increase opportunities are often forgotten a few months after they are introduced.  Ashford's technology is so dated, specifically the student classroom.  Students cannot interact with other students or their instructors on a video chat platform. Often times communication between a student and instructor breaks down because of this.

review_title: Frustration is a monotonic function of constantly increasing workload and constantly decreasing compensation

pros: I enjoyed helping students learn.  An opportunity to share decades of experience and teach classes that I truly enjoy.
cons: Administration constantly increases faculty expectations while decreasing faculty compensation.  Believe it or not, you can put in twice as much work in a small class while receiving half the compensation of a larger class! job_title: Admissions Counselor in Denver, CO
pros:
Good compensation for a call center atmosphere
Great people

They will be honest with you in saying this job is not for everybody.  It's very tough but rewarding when you get students.  Work environment is usually good unless you aren't enrolling students, then they are on you and will try to get you to quit.  Some teams and managers have a lot of fun, all depends on who you're with.
cons: Although they tell you during the interview process you'll be speaking with prospective students who want to go to school you'd be lucky to get one of those a week.  You will be calling the same people many times, and they've also been contacted by a number of other universities so they are understandably frustrated by how much their phone has been ringing.  If you aren't performing they'll try to get you to quit but can't outright just fire you right away because of scrutiny against for-profit universities in recent years.  There are technically no quotas but will be on you and make you feel like you don't belong if you're not enrolling.  Prospective "students" will likely not want to talk to you so you have to get them talking, then basically show them how bad their life is and how you have the solution that will change their life.

cons: good job the pace was fast

review_title: Great Place to Work if You are not in Admissions
job_title: Admissions Counselor in San Diego, CA
pros: If you do not work in admissions you will definitely feel like everyone is there to support you.  You will also have a wide ability to transfer and get free school.  The pay is good and the benefits are decent.
cons: If you are in admissions you are the hardest working part of the company and often feel the least valued.  Now I worked there in 2012 right before the massive layoffs and restructuring.  They've done a lot of changes to try to tip the scales in their bid for WASC accreditation.  I hear some more negative things have been added to the admissions counselor job but starting off at 18 an hour is better then most people would typically make.

review_title: Thought I had a promising future there...
job_title: Manager in San Diego, CA
pros: I loved what I did, I loved the people I worked with, and the tuition benefits were great!
cons: Lack of communication between departments, management, and executive leadership led to lots of wasted time on failed initiatives and often created more work instead of streamlining processes for employees to make their days more productive and less stressful.  Absolutely no job security, even if you are a good performer and show commitment and dedication to the organization.  Employees are constantly in fear that they will get laid off and they are constantly pushed to perform to unrealistic expectations.  While they offer generous vacation benefits, taking time off leaves you so far behind and stressed out that you either a) don't take vacation, b) work while on your vacation c) take vacation and then get inn trouble when you return because you can't catch up quickly from the amount of work that piled up while you were out.  Guess which option I went with?  I will give you a hint...it wasn't C.

job_title: University Advisor in San Diego, CA
pros: decent pay, free fitness facility, centrally located. blah blah balh blah
cons: If you want to go to work and be made to feel an inadequate failure this is the place for you.  They will tell you they are a "lead rich" company.  what they don't tell you is they buy the cheapest leads possible that they will admit only convert at 2%, give you anywhere from 100-200 of these leads a month then expect you to enroll 15 students on a monthly basis.  Due the math...IT's NEARLY IMPOSSIBLE TO SUSTAIN!  Then they give you a database of old leads that have been called hundreds of times and expect you to enroll from that.  They give a nice starting salary but make you mentally earn every penny and then some.  My entire team is constantly in fear of losing their jobs.  This is a classic fear based leadership model.  For a company that admittedly has a bad reputation in the community they have done nothing to change their public image.  Talk to ten people and I would bet at least one has worked for this place at some point and I would venture to guess they wouldn't have anything good to say about it.

job_title: Enrollment Advisor in San Diego, CA
pros: Great people to work with
cons: Seemed like a telemarketing company not a school

job_title: Admissions Counselor in Denver, CO
pros:
-Nice location.
-Meet great people.
-Decent benefits
cons:
-Don't let them fool you, this is a high pressure telemarketing job.
-Highly unethical company. CEO voted one of the greediest in America. High student fees with a very low percentage of that money actually going towards education.
-In spite of what you are told, there are quotas you are expected to meet. The catch is they are not allowed to tell you what the quota is, so you have to guess and hope you meet it.
-No incentives
-I was encouraged to lie to prospective students on multiple occasions to try to get them to enroll. 
-I once got called into a meeting with two managers and a director to discuss my posture and they way I sat at my desk. They wanted me to "look" more engaged as I talked on the phone.
-I had 10 bosses. All telling me to do things differently, all getting upset if I didn't do it their way, all looking over my shoulder constantly to monitor every minute of my day.

job_title: Admissions Counselor in Denver, CO
pros:
Good pay/benefits
Paid holidays
Nice office location
Paid public transportation
cons:
High employee turn-over rate. Call center atmosphere. Extremely poor management. Stress, stress and more stress. Zero job security.

If you have a conscience and fairly decent morals, this probably isn't the job for you. 95% of your "leads" haven't the slightest interest in going to school, yet as an AC you're expected to talk them into wanting to go. If you're lucky enough to rope someone in, you're expected to babysit them for the next 5 weeks (making sure they're complying with the very relaxed "attendance policy") until their financial aid comes through. If your student (a person you don't know personally and who most likely hasn't been responsible their entire life) drops, YOU are held responsible. 1 out of 10 students you enroll might actually follow through and attend class, but chances are they'll drop before they complete their first class and you will most definitely suffer the consequences. 
Every 3-6 months you can expect whispers of an upcoming company-wide layoff, and if your "numbers" (# of students attending class) aren't satisfactory, you will be gone. They'll tell you if you have no compliance violations, written or verbal warnings, or attendance issues you'll be fine, but this simply isn't true. Since this is "education" based they can't call it sales, but make no mistake, that's exactly what it is. You're expected to "change a life" (Ashford's fancy verbiage for selling education) or you won't have a job, plain and simple.

review_title: I've worked for 30 years (started when I was 14) and this is BY FAR the worst place I've ever worked.
job_title: Admissions Counselor in Denver, CO
pros: Benefits are good, but you have to wait three months to get them.
cons: People are promoted because they excelled in their jobs, not because they are good managers. I say promote the employees with skills, but please, please, please, give them some management training. Ashford University preys upon uneducated people in a low socioeconomic class. They promise them that everything will be better with a college degree. IF, they finish school with Ashford, they will have $50,000 more debt and will still likely have the same opportunities in the town in which they live. Ashford tells it's employees that they are working "warm" leads, but that is crap. You are cold-calling. NO QUESTION! You will spend day after day after day calling people that don't want to talk to you. You go through 2 weeks of training and then when you get to the "floor", you're told to forget EVERYTHING you learned in training. Why train then? I was not fired from this job, I chose to leave. I'm sure I could've stayed and even become a manager, but I just couldn't do it. I felt dirty working here. You will too if you go to work for Ashford!

job_title: Team Lead/Admissions Counselor in Poway, CA
pros: Great coworkers, great pay, great benefits for the San Diego area.  9-6 with an hour lunch.  Fun activities.  CLEAN work environment, nice building, great cafe (a little pricey), computer system for database leads
cons: STRESS. STRESS. STRESS.  If you are good, you are expected to do better.  If you are bad, expect to constantly be in fear of losing your job.  If you are ok, always feel pressured and confused.  If you can do this job, you can do any sales job.  They changed it from sales, by just changing the words... instead of an "app" you "changed a life".  They dangle the carrot that you can move up and I never saw anyone.  Saw a lot of managers lose their job.  Being a manager is said to be "the privilege of working a lot more hours for not a lot more pay."  Working with someone who is not motivated for 5 weeks, is very stressful.  I did great there, and still almost gave myself an ulcer.  DOG YEARS.  There is a 6 month expiration date on your head.

job_title: Enrollment Advisor in San Diego, CA
pros:
The opportunity to help people in the pursuit of lifelong goals and achievements was extremely rewarding.  Everyday you make a few hundred phone calls, but get a chance to build lasting relationships with people who are soon to forget fear and embrace confidence as they move on to reach a goal that may have seemed far, far away at one point in their lives. 
Ashford University and its parent company Bridgepoint Education also gives its employees a tuition remission program where an employee can finish an undergraduate degree, master's degree, or even a doctoral degree.
cons:
The hardest part of this job for me was sitting/standing at a desk all day.  Living in San Diego where the sun shines 90% of the year, being chained to a desk for 8 hrs+ can become very difficult.
Being told the position is not a sales job just did not feel right.  I understand the position is regulated by the Dept. of Education, but in reality it is a consultative sales position.  Seems to interfere with integrity.

review_title: This place SUCKS. Worst job of my life. Don't even bother working here.
job_title: Admissions Counselor in San Diego, CA
pros: It was a nice building, the bathrooms were nice, the cubicles were nice, a few people were nice, outside of all the gossip that happens here.
cons: Worst job ever. You are literally the annoying telemarketer that everyone hates and hangs up on. This is a telemarketing job, except worst because the leads they hand you are old and worn out. No one will want the useless degree that Ashford provides. They say they are "changing lives" by enrolling and I agree, lives are changed her for the worst. You try your best by becoming a professional scammer  to scam as many students as you can. And when they figure out you've scammed them, they dropped, then you get yelled at by your manager and director as to why they dropped. The turnover rate for this job is sky-high because you either are tried of being a brainless phone money and quit, or they will fire you and hire a new batch of phone monkeys. This can easily go down as one of the worst jobs any human being can be subjected to. It's not even worth applying, much less working here.

review_title: More of a sales job in a high-stress call center environment
job_title: Enrollment Advisor in San Diego, CA
pros: Learn about online education and programs if that is the field you are interested in, grow your skills as a counselor assisting potential students with their enrollment decisions. Nice cafeteria.
cons: Almost everything else. Low pay, high call volume, unfair enrollment quota requirements, count the minutes you take to the bathroom... be penalized if you are one minute late, be forced to participate in ridiculous "empowering" meetings with unfunny and uninteresting presentations and group activities, it's just AWFUL. The fear and pressure of losing the job is ever present. The "student counseling" part of  this job is minimal, most of it is production and high sales quota expectation. Like a robot basically, doing most of the work and earning the least amount of money. Living in San Diego, it's not possible to make it with their salary.  They are also very superficial. Well, I guess that's all California.

review_title: You have 6 months pay with a good attitude.
job_title: Enrollment Advisor in San Diego, CA
pros:
The pay is fairly decent.
The is a 1 month of paid training 
Depending on the manager and team, you can get paid to attend fun activities. 
If you survive, you can possibly get education discounts and other benefits.
cons:
Fellow coworkers can either be your biggest ally or worst enemy. 
If you work in the "health" undergrad programs, you have to sell degrees to people who typically want a certificate or programs (aka nursing) not available at the university.
You are blame for most bad leads.
There is a group mentality that pits you against other teams, and sometimes your own teammates. 
If you do get laid off, you are secretly lead out of the building by a manager. 
I honestly feel the company does not value employees.
Hiring and firing is a common way of life. 
There is an aux code mechanism where you need to put a code for everything you are doing at work. For example, employee have to put a code in to let their managers know that they went to the bathroom.....

job_title: Enrollment Services Advisor in San Diego, CA
pros: I've been here for over 6 years and this place has more Cons then Pros. The pros are they pay is constant, you are rewarded with more kindness when your on top, and they have good benefits.
cons: Where to begin? I'll try to keep this short. This place is what's known as a "revolving door".  They have always cut the bottom 25% of the entire building. Mass Layoffs used to be about twice a year. We are now down to a skeleton crew of high performers. They did raise our pay but not to the extent of the constant stress and anxiety that we all have. Nothing is EVER good enough!

review_title: Get in, get a free degree, and get out.
job_title: Enrollment Services Advisor in Denver, CO
pros: Free education. Getting a free master's degree is a huge pro, but it does tie you to the job. I made some of my best friends at Ashford. It can be a fun work environment. The job and metrics can be demanding, but it will teach you a lot of transferrable skills that you can take with you to any other job you do. Basically, you will get as much out of this job as you put into it, and you can grow your skill set while earning a degree.
cons: No advancement or growth opportunities. There is very little development after training, unless you have a manager who cares about that, but so few do. There is such pressure to hit your numbers that you sometimes forget you're actually working with real students. Not a lot of job security.  Overall, it's a great transitional job, but not something you would want to do forever. Get in, get a free degree, and get out.

review_title: Great Entry Level Opportunities, But Should Not Stay For Too Long-
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros:
Pros:
Free education for those who take advantage of it.
Great learning experience overall- how to interact with a variety of co-workers and managers, office politics, personally, I learned a lot of what-not-to-dos. 
Good people- most of the co-workers I had the pleasure of working with are decent, developed some great friendship and network.
cons:
Cons:
The company went through too many changes too often within short period of time, making employees anxious feel about job security, which is not secured, BIG yearly lay off is a norm. 
Little to no career development or care about employee retention- There is a running joke within the company that after 3 years or so working there, you are in your retirement age with the company, meaning you are there for too long already. Management supports that culture and made most of the more tenured employees feel unwelcome or laid them off. 
Middle management are often less experienced and less educated than their employees, therefore not receptive of employee suggestions, at the cost of the company's overall benefit, in fear that their employees might surpass them.

job_title: Associate in San Diego, CA
pros: None. Would give zero stars on all indicators  if that was an option.
cons:
Worse online teaching job of my 18 year career! Reasons: 

-30+ students in an online course 
-4 assignments per week per student is a lot to grade
-Faculty are supposed to give a ton of feedback. I calculated that with the amount of required feedback and 32 students I was making about $8/hr to teach an online class
-Faculty mentors were rude and attempted to bully. I would get nasty emails if it was 12 hrs past the "grading deadline" and my grading wasn't completed. I was treated like I was an idiot, not a professional with a PhD and years of hands on experience in my field
-Assigned reading had no publication date or were old. There were assigned articles that were more than 15 years old
- Students in the course I was teaching were one class away from having a 4 year degree yet lacked writing skills and knowledge of APA formatting. If they were getting the required amount of faculty feedback all along, why weren't they better writers? If I graded as I usually do, all of them would have failed. I had to really lower the standard to meet the students at their level.

job_title: Lead Admissions Counselor in Denver, CO
pros: Young Professionals, Recruiters did an amazing job in the hiring process all the people you work with are very outgoing, friendly, and personable. Loved most of my managers and all of my teams.
cons: Can make you question your moral compass. People that received promotions where terrible people who lied to potential students to get them to go to school with Ashford by saying they didn't need to pay back their federal loans that they could use their loans to buy frivolous things. The company over all is scary our CEO was voted number 1 for top dirtiest CEO's in the Huffingtons Post Last year. Also the company which is under bridgepoint education makes most of its money bt targeting military men and women because they have so much federal aid not be we support our troops ... Ashford only supports their wallet and if they do lot get WASC accreditation they will have no wallet to speak of

job_title: University Advisor in San Diego, CA
pros:
Amazing pay.
The food in the cafeteria wasn't bad.  I recommend the grilled cheese with bacon.
cons:
The University Advisors there seemed to be all about enrolling any student that came across their desks, regardless of it would be in that student's best interest.  I knew one of my students would run out of financial aid money at least a year before she would be able to graduate, and I was forced to enroll her without telling her about her situation.  With these tactics, Ashford was one of the schools that gave the industry a horrible reputation. 
The high pressure to meet numbers was clearly evident by how UAs constantly manipulated the system to steal students away from other UAs or lower reps.  
Long hours, but you could not get overtime unless the extra hours you were putting in were pre-approved.  This led to a lot of work being done off the clock.

review_title: It was Sales dressed up like education, but some skills were transferable
job_title: Admissions Counselor in San Diego, CA
pros: If you're looking to get a sales job and hit things like calls per day and make a calling strategy this is simply that. There are benefits for those who can get past the selling school to people who get afford it aspect. The people tend to be good because everyone is in the same boat and as long as you're not looking for personal fulfillment you could earn a paycheck and get paid holidays off.
cons: You are a number. If the school ever loses it's accreditation or if it isn't profitable it will close. I worked there during an accreditation scare and a lot of people jumped ship. The managers are generally promoted if they are good sales people, which doesn't always make for good managers. It can be stressful if you are behind, but if you can stay under the radar and produce they'll leave you along. If you don't produce, your number is up.

review_title: Initially Ashford University was a great company to work for...
job_title: Director in San Diego, CA
pros:
During the growth period (2008 - 2012) the company had quite a few opportunities for career advancement for those who showed initiative and leadership capabilities.  Just like most large corporations the department(s) you work in and Manager you work for will determine if you enjoy your job or not.  I have to say that I enjoyed each Manager that I worked for and department that I worked in.  

The direction of Ashford University definitely changed for the positive after Dr. Pattenaude became President / CEO.  He is an inspirational person who leads you to believe in the University mission.  Students & employees should be happy that Dr. P is at the helm of Ashford University.
cons:
Unfortunately, the reality of Ashford University for the past couple years:

- increased govt. scrutiny & competition in for profit higher education industry causing a stressful work environment and constant fear of losing accreditation and potentially being shut down
- year over year reduction in student enrollments causing layoffs 
- productive employees (Management & Staff) with quarterly / annual review scores of 4+ out of 5 being laid off due to budget cuts

job_title: Admissions Counselor in San Diego, CA
pros: A decent wage and strong benefits package.  Many really talented people (however they dont stay long)
cons: Faculty are expected to engage students when students are not engaged in school but focused on Financial Aid stipends.  Admissions Counselors are expected to "care for" student when this company (not school) care more about profits and the bottom line that its people or students.   Understandable this is a company on the stock exchange and all operations are focused around quarterly earnings, however this short sighted profit cycle always lead what other reviewers call AU -- "Profit driven" "Sales Driven" "Initiatives are ever changing with a lack of focus".   Executive management are profit puppets and lack true long sightedness in an ever challenging For Profit Education Industry. As long as the  "profit are over people policy" continues,  AU wil continue to stumble and stagnate along the for profit education timeline.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Clinton, IA
pros: The company is quickly growing, so in the right department there can be room for growth. Benefits for full time employees include tuition reimbursement for online courses.
cons: Working here, you get the impression that this is a company that fell backwards into success, grew too fast, and now doesn't know what to do with itself. Employees are underpaid compared to the industry, and you are treated differently depending on the state/location you work at. People are hired and fired for bizarre reasons, and the company often makes decisions only to end up cleaning up the mess made afterwards. The company does NOT offer maternity leave.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: You will meet some of the most amazing people of your life. Whether it be the ones you work with or the students. No doubt this place is an amazing stepping stone to gain good experience and the pay is great.
cons: They say they want students to graduate but they really don't care. At the end of the day we all have numbers to meet. It is a sales position. Even if you are producing you could still be on the chopping block at any moment. You will meet employees who have worked here for years and are still frightened they could be next. Students who are enrolled here are pushed to enroll and often drop out after the first course. Those students are the ones who should have never been enrolled in the first place. Because it is a sales job again your management will push you (if not do it themselves) to enroll that student.

review_title: Only if you really need to get a job fast
job_title: Financial Services Advisor in San Diego, CA
pros: The company culture is good and people are genuinely friendly.  It's a casual, young and vibrant work environment for the most part. Gym provided on site and cafeteria for employees. Free tuition for any degree program that you want to take. All classes are online unless you go to Iowa campus.
cons: Terrible communication between departments.  Unethical sales practices for enrolling students in the university (although things have gotten a lot better since I started working here).  Software used is extremely inefficient and needs to be updated. This is a call center job although the job description would like to make you think otherwise.  Cannot negotiate pay, and you will be underpayed regardless of education and experience.  It is a take it or leave it mentality because the job market currently dictates this for employers. It may be worth it if you want to pursue your degree for free with the company.

job_title: Enrollment Advisor in San Diego, CA
pros: Very casual workplace attire. Enrollment Services is a big department and there are some great personalities here. Most employees are between the ages of 24-35. It's a pretty chill work job, and they pay pretty well. There's plenty of opportunities for overtime.
cons:
Expectations are unrealistic. You can coast meeting the minimum expectations, or even be the best and exceed your goals, but every day is different and management hounds you for missing a goal or budget. It's understandable if they're disappointed looking at a team's performance, but they make you feel like a horrible employee even if you're a top performer on your team. 

Turn over rate is high. Most people leave after a year of experience here. 

Quality of students is poor. Quality of leads in general is poor. 

They micromanage to the core of all existence. 

Your mental health will be at risk here. They make you feel guilty for wanting to take a day off because it affects their business. And even if you earned two weeks of PTO, they tell you it's not likely to take that much time off at a time. 

A lot of pressure to generate referrals.

review_title: Could not stand sitting in a cubicle making 150+ calls a day
job_title: Admissions Counselor in Denver, CO
pros: Pay is pretty good for a recent college grad.  Employees are very fun to work with... all in the same age group (recently just graduated college).  Great location in downtown Denver.  Many restaurants and bars to go to after work.
cons: Everything.  Management is awful. They will treat you like a child.  Even if you exceed, you are still getting paid the same amount as everyone else.  This is a sales job, it needs to be commission-based.  Managers are all micro-mangers, you even have to let them know when you are going to the bathroom.  You have to work here for about 4-5 years to even be considered a promotion or raise.  Be prepared to make about 150+ calls a day until you finally find a potential student and beg them to come to our school and soon find out that they will drop out within weeks.

review_title: Finding Balance in an Unexpected Place
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros:
I have been able to find a healthy work/home/life balance with the flexibility I have found in my role here for the past two years. I have had the ability to work from home and get more accomplished while tending to sick children and taking care of situations that arise when needing a little more flexibility. 

The cross collaboration has also allowed me to develop skills beyond my role, and my degree path which only makes me a more well rounded employee. The leadership development track and access to nationally recognized leadership assessments aid in the development of employees in relational interactions and collaboration.
cons:
Leadership and organizational changes happen without warning and can leave gaps in place requiring people to pick up more work without additional compensation. 

Many roles are stationary and do not allow for growth vertically within the organization.

job_title: Admissions Advisor in San Diego, CA
pros: There are no pros at all.
cons: If this was the last place on earth you could work and had no money, I would rather foreclose on my home and be homeless than earn a wage here.  Management is negative, has unrealistic expectations, constantly criticizes your every move (why didn't you stay on the phone longer, why didn't you make your 300 calls today, why didn't you turn this person around, constant criticism and never anything positive).  They listen to all of your calls and find any reason to bring you in the office and rip you a new one.  They don't appreciate you or if your prospects can afford school, which most of them cannot, they have terrible leads.  If you don't mind being harassed my management, making 300+ calls a day and being micro-managed to the extreme, this is a place for you. You cannot trust management and they will find any reason to fire you.  You also have to clock in and out and God forbid you are a minute late due to long elevator lines and the computers not working and your time stamp is one minute off.  Almost everyone I have met had the same experience here, most got fired, I was lucky enough to take the high road and quit.

job_title: Admission Counselor in San Diego, CA
pros: You will have the opportunity to network with many young professionals in the San Diego area.  The buildings offer very nice amenities.
cons: Ashford University had to change it's compensation policy in accordance to a law change a few years ago.  Before the change, an admission counselor would be compensated with large ($15,000) raises every 6 months.  Now, if you are a good Admission Counselor and want to receive compensation you need to seek out management... or you will be pushed in that direction.  Problem is, a good Admission counselor does not necessarily make a good manager.  Too many young, inexperienced managers are promoted and unable to offer you their knowledge, time and unfortunately, their respect.  Good place if your okay with working for managers as young as 23 years old.  Also, you are just another number.  I've seen top performers get fired after two years of working there because they had a bad month.

job_title: Enrollment Services Advisor in Denver, CO
pros: The benefits and pay are great, and I love working in downtown Denver. The training I received before getting on the phones was phenomenal.
cons: Ashford is experiencing a lot of growth, and they are not able to manage it well. I am six months into my time here, and I still feel like I don't know what I'm doing. I know how to build rapport with students and walk through the process of applying. However when there are hurdles, mainly related to financial aid, I feel helpless. My manager in particular states that he wants us to be autonomous, but he hasn't been around to give us the tools necessary. Thankfully there are several people on my team who are willing to figure things out together and reach out to other managers. I would 80% of the time we are without our manager.

review_title: If You Have No Conscience This Is The Place For You!
job_title: Enrollment Advisor in San Diego, CA
pros:
Starting Salary
Initial Training Session
Cafeteria
Benefits
Cheer Leading Sessions are fun to observe
Attempting to help students make it through one of their lessons
cons: You are not hired to enroll students to offer them a chance at a higher standard of living or even a better life as you are told during the interview process and during training.  Rather you are here to perform hardcore telemarketing to non-qualified internet leads to people that thought they were applying for a job; but did not have the know how to exit the advertisement screen.  This for profit institution is not interested in education; but in targeting the disadvantaged/lower echelon of the working class such as single moms to bring in the Federal Student Loan monies to enhance their bottom line on Wall Street.  The goal is to get them to accept the federal student loan money, keep them in class for 5 weeks, and move on to the next victim which is why they have one of the highest drop out rates and federal student loan default rates.  Ask them how many people actually graduate!

job_title: Enrollment Services Advisor in San Diego, CA
pros: You will find diamonds (students) in the rough that keep you going at this job. If you have a good manger things can be pretty good for you. Helping students achieve their goals and supporting them is the best part. One of the best things is they offer tuition benefits for their employees so definitely take advantage of this.
cons: If you don't have a good manager things can be very difficult for you. The leads we are given are not always the easiest to work with. They changed their raise structure and recently screwed a lot of people out of their deserved raises. This job is difficult and i would only recommend it for the right reason.

review_title: Admissions is a rough gig, but so is any sales job
job_title: Admissions Counselor in San Diego, CA
pros: I find that far too many people on these sites are complaining about the way that they were treated as an Admissions Counselor at Ashford, when the truth of the matter is this is a sales job.  You can try to sugar coat it anyway you like, but in the end of the day, you are slanging degrees over the phone.  And that's ok.  And if you suck at this job, then maybe you should have been fired and should go do something else, because they pay you to enroll students.  All told, if you bust your butt, this is a good job.  Free gym onsite, cafeteria onsite.  Good hours, very few weekends (only during peak seasons like August and January).
cons: Parking at the Sunroad location sucks.  If you get there after 830am, you may be walking for a mile from wherever you end up finding parking in the surrounding community/business area.

review_title: Great for new grads - bad for those established in careers
job_title: Lead Admissions Counselor in San Diego, CA
pros: Great understandings of corporate life while striving for high goals.  You'll learn so much and really they will be there to teach you sales tactics and strategies. Starting pay is around 40K +- 5K
cons: Very secretive work environment  - say this not that, plenty of secret management conversations, if you're let go, it's stealth. This is a different style of management and maybe comes from the board since they have had a few CEOs in place. Damn dude- you're going to have ups and downs hold onto the people that try and let them develop as an employee. You'll build bonds with your fellow employees and hopefully be put with a manager that won't micro manage you. Unfortunately micro management comes from the top.  I have no clue how people last at this place for more than 5 years.  Seriously No clue!  either they are crazy, complacent, getting paid out , have blackmail to ensure employment or something.

job_title: Education Partnership Representative in Denver, CO
pros: By far the best job I've ever had. The flexibility and trust given to remote employees is amazing, and you can see the investment they make in everyone on the team. The job requires creativity and collaboration, and my manager gives me the support I need to work towards goals. I worked as an Enrollment Advisor for over two years before moving to this department, and I am much happier in this position, however, I am thankful to have the background knowledge from enrollment. Plus, I was able to get my Masters degree with no out of pocket for me.
cons: Working remote presents challenges, but the University flies everyone out to San Diego for team building twice a year to combat this. There are some issues people have with non-profits in general, and Ashford does face scrutiny for this.

job_title: Finance in San Diego, CA
pros: Gym on site, 12 paid holidays, can accumulate 160 hours of paid time off with 5+ years of employment, 80 hours paid time off prior. Some people are really trying to improve policies and procedures. Not working in the Admissions Department.
cons:
Admissions Department has it the worst. High stress, high turn over rate, micromanaged. They starting pay is no longer worth it as they have decreased it significantly. Zero job security, expect layoffs twice a year. 
Lack of tools and resources. Technology is outdated and when a new software is implemented it causes issues for long periods of time. Employees are resistant to new technology. No room for growth you can't even apply for a promotion if you've received a minimal increase within six months.

review_title: The life of a student advisor
job_title: Student Advisor in San Diego, CA
pros: Good pay, decent insurance options, and a good  level of autonomy. I can come in almost any hour in the morning I want as long as I work my 8 hours and leave before 6pm. I work on my own pace and learn which tasks are a priority to complete. Coaching and counseling students feel rewarding. They allow quite a bit of overtime. The feeling of helping a student through their journey to graduate is great too. I saw a couple of my students at their graduation and it made it all worth it.
cons: The people I work with are incredible, and the managers are pretty cool people too. I feel frustrated with the more business-minded leaders push high expectations on the advisors that I feel like a sales person trying to keep students in.

job_title: Admissions Counselor in Aurora, CO
pros: I worked with some genuinely amazing and down-to-earth people. This seems to be a common quality that Ashford looks for in interviews: earnest and genuine demeanor. There is genuine opportunity here. If you can trudge through the admissions position and apply for a promotion--you are set here. The pay is also more than fair for the type of work. The insurance options however are terrible and over-priced.
cons: It really is a terrible place to work. Despite the fact that quotas ( in the traditional sense) are restricted in the education sector, Ashford has them and they are frankly ridiculous. Morale is terrible and layoffs are common. We call and email the most vulnerable of our society (people that are unemployed and desperate) and provide a degree--upon completion of a program-- that isn't worth the paper upon which it is printed. Fun stuff

review_title: Not a great workplace unless your right out of college!
job_title: Matriculation Coordinator in San Diego, CA
pros: A huge company that employees a big number of people in the community.
cons: They mass hire and then weed out the people that don't fit in their 'culture' and lay them off/fire them.  The majority of the Ashford employees are very young, mostly early to mid twenties.  The job training is mediocre and the expectations are unrealistic.  They basically treat every job position like your in sales, you must meet daily and weekly numbers and goals.  If your slow or don't make numbers then your days are numbered.  The pay is very low for the amount of stress and work.  Its no wonder the huge turnaround and massive layoffs this company has faced the last 4 years.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: Great management, great employee culture, excellent benefits packages, Beautiful office building, close to freeways, Employee events
cons:
The way in which they create performance goals is based on a person's salary, but yet they provide no more resources for those with higher goals who are higher paid.
They took away the work-from-home for those of us who had been able to do it. They also are requiring weekends now.

job_title: Admissions Counselor in Denver, CO
pros: Great pay benefits etc, only reason this gets a 2 is i was unemployed for a long time before then and wanted to get the hell out of the state i lived in before this one
cons: You get hired you have no idea its a sales job they sell it like youll be a college counselor or something, Bad management, horrible leads (im talking most of the numbers youd call were disconected or nobody EVER answered the phones em, super shady company, youd get a hard time if you didnt enroll enough people, even though thats been illegal since 1992 in the private education industry. The guys at the top loved to pretend that we were doing it legit. I remember one time my manager gave me a hard time because I didnt enroll someone living in their car and goes "well they could go to the library"

job_title: Enrollment Advisor in San Diego, CA
pros: Great benefits, working schedule, long lunch, semi decent gym onsite, onsite health clinic
cons:
Pay seems great at first, high stress, uses scare tactics to increase performance.

Overall lack of respect for people.

Bribe employees with free donuts, ice cream, etc. to try and make the "best places to work" list.
 
When your are let go from your position, they make you take a walk of shame to the elevators in front of all your coworkers. Forget about getting your personal items back in a timely manner. They take weeks and don't even return everything. If you are considering a position here, I would use it as an absolute last resort when you are in desperation mode.

job_title: Admissions Counselor in San Diego, CA
pros: You meet very friendly and personable people who genuinely get along with each other. It's fun to spend lunch or breaks with these people.
cons: It can not get much worst than this in the corporate world. The job is terrible. You make phone calls all day and night and get yelled at and hung up on when the 2% of people you call that actually pick up the phone. The other 98% of time time, you are a brainless phone monkey, making call after call to no avail. The director and manager are pressured by the big boys above, so they take it out on you. You are pressured to no end, and there is absolutely nothing you can do about it. Some admissions counselors even resort to selling education to their friends and families, but do not realize that they will only hurt those that they love by doing this. The degree provides absolutely no value and all the talks of "changing lives" are merely broken promises. Please do not take this job no matter what.

job_title: Financial Services Advisor in San Diego, CA
pros: Entry level business acumen and operational mechanics are sound for a learning environment. There is a lot that you are responsible for within the company, level of responsibility, and commitment to projects allows a grand breeding for customer service based business to be learned.
cons: At times there was large and prevalent disconnect between those that are implementing new projects, processes, and ownership to projects and those that are actually implementing or practicing them on the daily basis The dynamic of the company has a million one off situations that will need to be worked and accessed - as that type of environment that is to be expected senior staff is hard to track down in order to assist with a resolution that you may be able to attain without approval.

job_title: Adjunct Teaching Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros: I worked in the online writing lab. The people who were my direct supervisors were great. Ashford also offers faculty an easy to use online classroom format. Working with the students was enjoyable. I miss the job a lot.
cons: I would still be working there if the parent company had not decided to close down the entire online writing lab. They didn't even have the courtesy to let the employees know and give us time to find other jobs. We simply received a form letter, along with everyone else on their mailing list, congratulating themselves on their wise cost cutting decision. The letter was sent only four weeks before the closure.

review_title: Don't work here if you have an ounce of integrity
job_title: Enrollment Advisor in San Diego, CA
pros: Many opportunities for advancement, transfer to other departments, good benefits. Performance based matrix means you can go from making 36K when you start, and 6 months later (if you are a top performer) making $90K+. They also pay for your education if you take classes through them. "College Fridays" one Friday a month, they provide pizza, beer and give out employee awards.
cons: Cut throat business model. After 7 months of working there, only 5 of the 30 in my training group remained. (Were either fired or quit). Expect to make 200+ phone calls per day. If you're not hitting your numbers you are expected to come in early, stay late and work weekends to make extra phone calls. You will be contributing to the student loan bubble - convincing low income and low socio-economic people to take out huge student loans. Majority of them will not finish school, but will be stuck with these loans for a very long time. Also they lie to students about how many credits they accept, only to break the news to students AFTER they've already enrolled. Not sure how execs sleep at night.

review_title: Only good if you're desperate for cash/benefits while you actively look for other jobs
job_title: Admissions Counselor in San Diego, CA
pros: The team environment here is great. You see these people literally 24/7 and some even become your best friends.
cons: Don't kid yourself this job is numbers driven it is all about producing students. They'll try to sell you that you're "changing lives" but all you're doing is roping people in to spend tens of thousands on an online education that most of them can't even pass the most basic class. This " university" does not care about its student or employees. It care about making a profit. There is a huge turnover rate. If you don't make your sales quota you are fired.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: The only good thing here are the co-workers
cons: Where do I start. This place is ran with such carelessness. They do not care about their employees at all, and seem to want you to be unhappy. They continually instill fear in their employees. I think people stay at this place because they end up meeting great co workers here, but this place is similar to The Hunger Games. Managers, Directors, and DVP's are some of the most uneducated people I have met. Most of these people earned their degrees at Ashford University. All upper management feels an odd sense of entitlement and our promotions are handle by an unorganized department in which you will never see/meet and they handle everything. Quite silly, I am sure under all of this their are hamsters spinning a wheel somewhere keeping this place going.

job_title: Lead Faculty in Remote, OR
pros: It's a full-time position with a lot of responsibility. I am forced to manage and deal with things that most faculty never see, learn, or understand.
cons: I've actively been seeking work elsewhere with better wages, lower workload, and better benefits (which is literally any other institution). I've learned, however, that having Ashford on your CV is a black mark that cannot be overcome. So, for now, I am left on this sinking vessel with my conscience screaming for me to jump ship. New leadership is highly concerning. We lost leadership from "real" higher ed and have reverted back to business-model profit-centered leadership. All strides we made in the last five years are being lost.

review_title: Definately not the job as advertised!!
job_title: Admissions Counselor in San Diego, CA
pros: The company offers relatively good benefits.  You will meet good, socially aware people.
cons: This is a 'glorified' telemarketing position.  It will require 200-300 outbound calls per day generally calling the same numbers day in and day out.  The focus is primarily on enrolling new students, any new students that will enroll whether the student is prepared or a good fit for the programs.  There is no retention department so admissions counselors are must retain the students enrolled and also enroll the same level or greater students.  It's no wonder overall graduation rate is under 20 percent.  Just as student retention is low so is employee retention in this position.  In this role, compromising one's integrity will become an issue for the socially aware.  I would not recommend this job!

job_title: Admissions Counselor in San Diego, CA
pros: Calling 300 to 400 people a day from cold call resource lists will really sharpen your skills to me efficient in your sales the moment a live person answers their phone. This job is great for building your sales skills in the sink-or-swim sort of way.
cons: This is a very numbers driven job. While that can be a great motivating factor, it gets stressful when expectations cannot be met and the reason for that is truly out of your control. The fear of being let go at any moment is a real and constant fear that affects the energy of the workplace.

job_title: Enrollment Advisor/Team Lead in San Diego, CA
pros: Benefits are great. Met some of my best friends there.
cons: I worked there year ago and there was completely different cons than there are now. Having to "sell" people to better their lives and further their education is very tough. You must learn to compartmentalize and just enroll! If not, its your job. If you can get past that then you're good.  Some of the top dogs who founded Ashford have left. That says something about the overall business and where it is headed. If you can dial all day and sell yourself, you will be fine.

job_title: ESA in San Diego, CA
pros: Flexible schedule with overtime opportunities, not stressful if you are doing well... structured and unstructured at the same time, they let you learn your own style (in my experience)
cons: Most managers suck.  Lots of yelling and crosstalk when you are trying to work without any regard to what you are doing - this can last for sometimes up to an hour, managers WILL pay attention to everyone and report back to your manager even if they only had seen a portion and do not have a complete understanding of what is going on - you will not win these arguments.

review_title: Great pay, great people - horrible corporate environment
job_title: Enrollment Advisor in Denver, CO
pros: The pay is great for what you do. It is relatively stress less and they can't fire you based on production. The people you will work with are fun and will become your friends.
cons: Micromanagement is an understatement. You have "codes" to let management know what you are doing at your desk, and they can see it on their computer at any time. You literally have to tell them (with your aux code) that you're going to the bathroom, and if you are in "Personal" time for too long they will hunt you down and ask you what you're doing. Not to mention that for profit college is mostly a clever way to steal Financial aid money from the government.

job_title: Admissions Counselor in Denver, CO
pros: Benefits are good. So is having an Eco-Pass to use the bus/light rail.
cons: Some of the directors (and managers) are untrustworthy and unscrupulous. Their actions have been under close scrutiny lately by the senior leadership team (thank goodness). Hopefully they will be replaced by new director--and not a moment too soon. The current Directors are narcissistic and engage in the "blame game" by finger-pointing at the Admissions Counselors for not meeting enrollment quotas, when in fact, the entire system seems "broken".  Simply put, some counselors (who are not part of the Ashford clicque) are unsupported or shunned by management and just preached at.

review_title: Stressful at times but I liked it
job_title: Student Advisor in San Diego, CA
pros: Great colleagues, always willing to help each other out, made lasting friends, great pay but was not equal across the board as I was grandfathered in at a higher salary. Good benefits and experience which helped me land a promotion at another school. Despite hurdles, they are at least trying to move in the right direction especially for online education.
cons: Hard push for numbers which sometimes are not within your control. If you can survive admissions then you can survive pretty much any working environment. Upper management is quick to implement large scale changes without fully vetting them which can lead to lower level employees scrambling to clean up the mess.

job_title: Adjunct Professor in Portland, OR
pros: Flexibility, Paid on Time, New LMS, Steady stream of classes.
cons: Peer reviews, unqualified students, work load.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: Met a lot of great co-workers along the way
cons:
Please do yourself the favor and avoid this place at all costs. I worked here almost 5 years and this place will use you, chew you up, and spit you out. Leadership is as corrupt as Trumps administration and management are overpaid brainwashed puppets.  You are nothing but a number and only have one sole responsibility which is selling an education to the less fortunate and uneducated population of the US. There is no room for growth opportunities or career advancements. The only thing you will gain is an ulcer from the stress of a cut throat untrustworthy environment. This is place  unethical  and will make you feel incompetent- please think twice before you work here because you deserve and are better than that! Use your skills and knowledge where they will be valued and not shut down. 

Any rave reviews about working here is probably part of the  Executive Assistants  job requirements. Seriously, do your research and think twice before you decide to work here. I wish I did.

review_title: People are great but the job sucks
job_title: Student Advisor in Denver, CO
pros: Young and smart co-workers but that's about it. Even directors do not have much say in how operations are run, they are just puppets.
cons: Unethical place to work.  Homeless and computerless students are enrolled in the university with little to no chance to succeed.  The university does not always check to make sure a student has graduated high school.  Students are not told how many credits will transfer into the university until after they are enrolled.  Enrollment advisors make empty promises to students just to get them to enroll.  Very high drop out rates.  No one has any idea what direction AU is headed because leadership is non-existant.

review_title: Reasonable Pay for too much stress
job_title: Admissions Counselor in San Diego, CA
pros: My co-workers are so positive and friendly. The managers want to lift you up and help you be successful.
cons: The number of students you enroll and retain will dictate whether you are fired from the job in one month or some random number of months down the line. It is never clear when you are safe from getting laid off. They say that there is a system of a verbal warning, written warning, and the official lay-off. It is not true. Yesterday, there were hordes of people getting called into the director's office to get laid off. Some were not doing well with numbers but others were meeting expectations. What a disrespectful way to treat employees. I will never work here again.

review_title: A phone monkey, a sleazy sales job, with horrible management, don't work here.
job_title: Admissions Counselor in San Diego, CA
pros: The regular employees were so nice.
cons: This company BLOWS! You will sit on the phones all day and try to recruit students whether they are homeless or living in their cars (yikes!). Ashford, wake up, and please answer to your employees and students needs instead of your shareholders. This is NOT an educational institution, this is a corrupt corporation only interested in getting rich from the top down. They will work you to the bone, threaten to fire you when they are the ones giving HORRIBLE leads to begin with, and try you as no more than a number - easily replaceable at any moment. Hands down, the worst company I have ever been apart of and I doubt I will ever see a company as bad as Ashford. Steer clear of this disaster folks.

review_title: Adjunct Instructors are asked to do too much for SO little
job_title: Adjunct Instructor in San Diego, CA
pros:
Their training is thorough
The students are kind and most work hard
The provide solid instructor resources (though some are not thorough)
cons:
The management limits instructors to twelve hours of work a week, though it is clear to all involved that this is not enough time to complete the work. In essence they are asking people to work extra hours with no pay
The management micromanages everything and the course structure is very rigid (more than at any other university I've taught)
I heard that they have done away with TAs which would significantly increase an instructor's work (especially for general education courses) but they refuse to raise the salary.

job_title: Financial Services Advisor in San Diego, CA
pros: Great benefits, nice coworkers and management staff. Free work out room and access to cafeteria with snacks and sandwiches and some other warm food. Beautiful offices. Typical hours and good PTO, paid holidays.
cons: The quality of students is variable, and they are often rude to those in financial aid. I had other positions in this company and much preferred them to this position, which was mostly dealing with students who were not prepared to be taking online classes and the financial burden that it entails. Did not want to be realistic about their financial aid options.

review_title: A sinking ship going from the glory days of For Profit Edu, to hide under the umbrella of Non Profit
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: They employee many in San Diego & Denver
cons:
For Profit Education was a cash cow and those days are done.   Any of the talented management has left because they saw the writing on the wall.   The boiler room  management & thinking is the so ingrain in  DNA and fabric of the culture that is creates hellish environment where friends throw friends under the bus.  VPs are clinging on to the last crumbs of the gravy train and reign by fear to squeeze every application dollar from staff and students.       The "non profit" survival strategy will allow this environment to persist under the radar because the culture is a cancer that will never leave Ashturd and Bridgepoint. 

Bridgepoint is Ashturd and Ashturd is Bridgepoint

job_title: Enrollment Counselor in San Diego, CA
pros: I made some great friends, enjoyed the paid training and competitive pay plus benefits.  Thorough paid training.  I enjoyed helping students succeed.
cons: Ashford cares about making money above the success and needs of the students they enroll.  They spend a lot of time convincing employees that they are helping people but the ones who succeed do so only by shady practices.   The management and staff are the most dishonest, morally appalling group of people that I have ever worked with in 20 yrs.   90% turnover rate from what I witnessed.

job_title: Admissions Advisor/Recruiter in San Diego, CA
pros: Really great culture. There are a lot of really good people there who really want to help people. Ashford knows how to hire people with big hearts. They will make it seem like you will be entering a job that you will be able to have a career in and thats far from the truth. Great pay and benefits. Great food in cafeteria.
cons: This job will literally stress you out to the point you are sick!!! They don't give the students what they are selling and expect for you to keep the students enrolled. You are responsible for the students every move. People get promoted unfairly. Turn over rate is extremely high. You are lucky if you make it beyond 6 months.

job_title: Online Faculty in Orlando, FL
pros:
While the university is for-profit, it seems committed to good education and a good atmosphere. Online adjunct faculty receive good support and attention. You are not left to fend for yourself. the company has a good, serious culture and atmosphere.
the work is steady. There is no suspense because you now you will always teach the next class and the next, year-round, if you do a competent job.
cons:
The course material is so basic, it is borderline dumb. And it is STILL a challenge for students.  If you get real strict with grading, the students have emotional breakdowns.

Also, the amount of work is not commensurate with the pay. You are required to give detailed feedback for each discussion post every week. And thew grading. The pay is peanuts in comparison.

job_title: Graduate Student in San Diego, CA
pros: Developing one's overall cultural workforce ethic takes deep intrinsic study habit disciplines, and Forbes School of Business has a dedicated staff of doctors, professors and advisors that successfully illustrates these necessities to better business sense.
cons: Speaking of my personal ascertainments concerning diligence, one must be focused on what it is that their are trying to accomplish and succinct in their efforts to really create an effective discipline of requirements the hierarchical forces of  Forbes School of Business "or" any other rigorous university program will require.

review_title: Great at first, company is going downhill fast. Sales job.
job_title: Admissions Counselor in Denver, CO
pros: People you meet & help. Loved my students however managers always pushed for more, PTO and benefits were about what's expected for a college graduate
cons: Managers always want more, never felt a sense of satisfaction. Saw friends laid off that were great at the job however were not "meeting expectations" which were set at an absurdely high level. Resources (leads) provided are not interested, may speak with 1 in 100 people who are, then you're competing against many other schools that are able to offer benefits you can't due to costs, accessibility etc.

job_title: Admissions Counselor in San Diego, CA
pros: Helping students and your co workers were really cool. It would be the perfect job if they followed the management strategies they taught in their courses and in the management training programs. Also this company is extremely political and everyone in admissions seems to work in fear of losing their jobs
cons: Regardless of time with the company you were treated like a number. Your students also regardless of their situation was treated like a number. Management is so far removed from the daily activities of the staff they do not have a realistic ideal of what they job inlets

job_title: Enrollment Service Advisor in San Diego, CA
pros: co workers were cool, like every other place I have worked. certain management is okay, the rest, treat you like crap. Please don't go into this place. decent pay and benefits, not worth it to hate everyday of your life though.
cons: You have been warned. This place is a prison. You are constantly monitored and watched to make calls. Calls to a database that are old and outdated and you call people who have no money to go school, so ultimately you manipulate these people into taking out student loans. It is all fake, the company is sinking. Look it up in the news. These people who say they request information, are looking for help, not getting trapped in a system that is built for them to fail. This is a company, one that is there to make money, and that is it. You are worked like a slave and if you don't sell, you will be fired in 6 months, I guarantee it. Please don't do, be a better person.

review_title: Very bad place to work for!
job_title: Adjunct Instructor in Clinton, IA
pros: A certain amount of flexibility in online teaching, but that is all.
cons: No true support from this company; lack of any real orientation and training; administration is a joke, as there are no real administrators - just sales personnel; as an adjunct, you have no real authority in your classroom - a student can complain and get his or her grade changed by an administrator without any investigation into the matter or input from the course instructor; in short, it's as if they are simply a "front" for money making and not interested in what real education is all about.

job_title: Enrollment Advisor in San Diego, CA
pros: Great pay and benefits, solid training program. There were three weeks of intensive training that really equip you to do well before you even get to your desk and on the phones.
cons: Very sales-oriented, which was not the job I thought I signed up for. They claim to not cold call people, but ultimately that's what's going on. They tend to use fear and competition as a motivator, like if you don't enroll enough students you have to fear for your job. Definitely did not like that kind of high-pressure atmosphere.
