job_title: University Advisor in San Diego, CA
pros: I am in admissions and we have been moved to the parent company as of May 29th 2015, however I worked under the Ashford umbrella since Feb 2008.  It used to be a lot of fun in admissions, but the other departments appear to enjoy their days.
cons: The management hasn't grasped yet why enrollments are decreasing, and are too unwilling to change the way they have done business since 2005.  Because of this there have been a lot of layoffs, down 40% from our high in 2011 of 5,000 employees.

review_title: A Institution of Take their money
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: The people I worked with were Amazing and the cafeteria food was great.
cons: It is Cattle call, cold calling and a numbers based college. They didnt care if the students were learning or not and I had students emailing me who didnt have a grasp of the English Language (their/there; youre/your) yet were Grad degree students. The Managers were a Joke. They dated each other and swapped like we were at a dance. One week if your Manager was dating someone who could help you they would. If they broke up then they wouldnt help our team out at all. I truly believed I was in a HS setting. I was hired for one job yet placed in another based off of my Education Level/ Skillset yet the pay was Poverty. I went back to teaching at Community COllege with less stress and more money.

review_title: Experienced Director from traditional higher education
job_title: Director in San Diego, CA
pros: Innovative, student focused, hard working employees. Family atmosphere where you get to work with your best friends. Fairly compensated. Strong leadership.This was one of my best experiences in higher education after having worked in every sector. We worked with great people every day doing great things for students and alumni.
cons: Leadership at parent organization are not as respected as leadership at the university are. Benefits have increasingly gotten worse in last couple of years. A lot of lay offs. Over the last couple years environment has become less positive and engaging.

review_title: Ashford is a big corporation that treats its employees as numbers.
job_title: Admissions Operations Coordinator in Denver, CO
pros: They offer an education benefit that allows employees to earn free or discounted degrees from all three of their institutions. They also offer competitive health and vision benefits.
cons: The leaders are unethical and lack vision. The low level employees pay the price for poor decisions made by the executive team. They reached a plateau in 2013 and suffer from an identity crisis.

review_title: Only if you really need a job ... but don't get stuck here.
job_title: Finance in San Diego, CA
pros: You will meet a lot of interesting people from different backgrounds.  My favorite part of working here was the friends that I made.
cons: Intelligence, loyalty, and hard work will get you nowhere.  Management is only concerned about the loud people who come up with "ideas for change".  The only reason these ideas are needed is because the business model itself is failing.  Only work here if you desperately need a job and don't expect the company to care for you or treat you as anything but just a warm body.

job_title: Readiness Advisor in Denver, CO
pros: Management is very understanding to new employees. The work is pretty stressful, but if you are patient and take it one task at a time, you will get the hang of it. Everyone is incredibly nice and very helpful. This job has taught me a lot, not only about higher education, but about myself as well.
cons: Was offered a position initially in Enrollment, then they offered me a position in Advising because they decided they didn't need more people in enrollment. When they offered me the new position, they did not send me a job description, which was a little odd.

job_title: Anonymous in San Diego, TX
pros: Benefits and coworkers. There are some great people in positions that are going no where.
cons: Unfortunately, there is no hope for this company. The mid-level management is manipulative and corrupt. The company uses trickery to scare the employees into enrolling more people into their programs. It is well understood that it is a business and they are there to make money. The students and lower level employees are who suffer. I would not recommend this company or the school. Trust me you can find a better job overall, don't be inticed by pay. And the truth is, if you don't preform they will FIRE you anyway. Save yourself the anxiety of working for a place where you can never win. Don't believe me, google their reviews: students, staff and the government. Abandon Ship!!!

job_title: Director of Admissions/Divisional Vice President of Admissions in San Diego, CA
pros: Helping others to achieve goals, Pay, training, Paid time off, co-workers, facilities, business casual work environment, educational benefits.
cons: It is difficult to utilize your earned Vacation benefits. Current educational policies hinder your abilities to help students fully achieve there goals.  Due to the current state of this industry there is lack of growth opportunities, due to the economic climate of this business. Unfortunately due to the industries current condition their is constant change, and high turnover,

job_title: Admissions Counselor in San Diego, CA
pros:
Steady hours
Good benefits
Good manager
Overtime pay
cons:
High-pressure to the point that it impedes success.
ZERO JOB SECURITY - termination is constantly looming and makes it harder to do one's job.
Almost no positive feedback.

job_title: Adjunct Faculty in Iowa City, IA
pros:
health benefits
staff are excellent to work with across the company
cons:
-Executives do not value the front-line staff doing all the hard work.  Staff are treated like a resource to be exploited, not valued.
-High executive pay and bonuses make them oblivious to the effects of not getting cost of living raises for staff.  Great companies make sure their staff are valued and appreciated with pay increases.
-Executives hold all employees responsible for low level student performance (read: failure) in the classroom and can be fired for those data.
-The company is run by numbers crunchers first and foremost.   Failure to make your "numbers" and you are terminated, regardless if its good advising or helping the students.  Numbers rule ALL.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: Easy to make friends, on-site cafeteria and gym facilities, transferring to other departments is easy. Tuition free education for those who want to take advantage of available programs (quality is questionable though). You can do work and listen to your music at the same time.
cons: Managers acting holier than thou, micromanaging instead of managing, promotion is a joke. Questionable practices in certain departments.  Admissions counselors make more money than other staff even though they don't have undergraduate degrees.  Company is really numbers-oriented but denies it.  School tries to place up to par with (probably cheaper and better quality) online programs from "traditional" campuses but does poor job of actually disclosing WHERE their graduates work (other than Ashford/Bridgepoint).

job_title: Enrollment Services Manager in Denver, CO
pros: Ashford has a great culture and frequently offers employees opportunities to be creative in their role/participate in community events.  Employees are encouraged to take initiative with cultural events they are passionate about.  The University provides all the tools that employees need to grow and develop in their role so they can best assist students in their roles.  I genuinely feel that my supervisor cares about me and I look forward to coming in to work each day to spend time with coworkers who have become friends.
cons: Would like to have the opportunity to work from home at times.  This would be a beneficial option for employees who live far from the office and would be an attractive option to potential new employees.

job_title: Enrollment Services Advisor in San Diego, CA
pros: Nice building, free gym, some of the greatest people to work with, overtime during high peak periods
cons: Its not about the students, it's about the numbers. You will try to enroll students who aren't ready to get into college. You must hand hold almost all of them.. The cafeteria even screws you over with the high prices. Management blows too, only care about making numbers and close to nothing about it's employees. Pushes you to keep students in class when they are failing big time only to restart and fail again. Someone is ALWAYS listening to your conversations and its a favoritism environment. IT IS A CALL CENTER DONT BE FOOLED. Company is losing a lot of money and puts too much pressure on the inside to generate profit

job_title: in Fredericksburg, VA
pros: The university offers an easy to use online teaching interface.  Certain parts of classroom communications are standardized such as the syllabus.  The curriculum is okay, but could be more challenging for students.  Textbook is digital, which enables easy searching.
cons: Classes are very large, leaving little time to provide quality feedback to students.  Pay is low in relation to the amount of time required to be an effective faculty.  Students frequently complain about  Inconsistent expectations from faculty--for example, some faculty enforce APA standards, others don't..

job_title: Admissions Counselor in Denver, CO
pros: Co-workers who I am still friends with, Somewhat "regular hours" (although Sat OT sometimes expected), 401k (vests after 4 years) & benefits, and location on 16th street in downtown Denver. Pay was average.
cons: Saw dozens of friends laid off when I was not, management is not knowledgeable, less about helping students more about enrollment #'s, Ashford has a hard time competing w/ other online programs and accreditation was compromised making enrollments more difficult towards the end of my time w/ the company.

review_title: Started out great. Good vibrant environment, low stress, good location and training. Then after a few months reality hit
job_title: Enrollment Services Advisor in Denver, CO
pros: Location, some mangers are positive and supportive, pay, and training. Hours are good. Given bus pass when employed. Secure building, gym.
cons: Majority of managers are stressed out and take it out on their teams, lack of training after a couple of months, disregard by higher ups for overall employee happiness, job is not full filling and mangers struggle to keep moral up.

review_title: You never feel secure-never a day where layoffs are not discussed in some capacity
job_title: University Advisor in San Diego, CA
pros: 2 great things-Great money as a University Advisor, and so many amazing and fun people. I made a lot of great friends through working there. I had a fantastic manager who was 1 in a million there, but still couldn't protect you from execs from above in regards to making you feel comfortable about keeping your job.
cons: Constant talk about them eliminating positions, massive layoffs etc. You could never really relax knowing that you did a good enough job (to keep it) at the end of every day.

review_title: Worse and worse year after year...
job_title: Faculty in San Diego, CA
pros: There's always a lot of work to be done. It's never slow or quiet.
cons: Take home pay is less every year. In fact, there is no increase in pay for 2016, even for those who worked hard all year, expecting a merit increase. The benefits are the worst in the industry, and costs go up every year. It is becoming a nightmare and I am actively looking for employment elsewhere. It is a shame.

job_title: Admissions Counselor in San Diego, CA
pros: Pay and benefits-good enough to sustain you while you actively seek different employment
cons: This place is a joke! You can't get a hold of departments, you are treated like crap and told that you have to deal with it, poor managers and directors. This place is money driven and that is it. You are constantly stressed out to meet unrealistic sales goals. You are putting poor people in debt just to keep your job because if you don't sign a certain amount of people up a month, you are fired. You are constantly told how you suck and are worked like you are in a modern day sweat shop. Please don't work here!

review_title: One of the worst places I've ever worked
job_title: Admissions Counselor in San Diego, CA
pros: I worked at Trashford from 2010 to 2013.  The pay wasn't too bad if you hit your numbers, but this was back when they'd give you more money for enrolling more students (illegal now, and they were exploiting a loophole back then).
cons: Terrible management from the top down, extreme pressure to enroll students regardless of academic preparedness. One student actually had severe multiple sclerosis and was on megadoses of morphine (like 50mg!!) daily.  She said she wanted to go to school but just talking to her you knew she wasn't physically well enough to succeed long-term.  Did I feel good about this?  No, but that's for-profit education. She lasted 3 weeks - I wonder how she's managing paying off those student loans...

job_title: Admissions Counselor in San Diego, CA
pros: Great pay for the work required. Hour long lunch, good facility, people are really nice.  Bachelor's Education paid for after 6 months of employment. Benefits are above average.  Opportunities for advancement.
cons: Monotonous work, micromanaged to the second, High turn over rate, must meet enrollment goals or you are "coached."  You are an "admissions counselor" but really you are a sales telemarketer for a for-profit school calling leads and influencing enrollment.

job_title: Adjunct in San Diego, CA
pros: Nothing really. I mean it.
cons: Worst paying adjunct job of my life. Supervisors were absent but reviewed courses and would try to intimidate. No on in HR there to talk to, no one in the administration returned multiple calls or emails. Unprofessional place to work, students are ill equipped to deal with their work loads, are passed into coursework they do not understand and can neither write nor add or subtract. The worst thing about this place is that the students are coerced to enroll in programs they are ill suited for. The curriculum is static, the instructors no more that pawns who are required to make posting banks and not personalize responses because sometimes over 40 students are in a class. Just horrific in all ways.

job_title: Student Advisor in San Diego, CA
pros:
Great team and wonderful boss!  This is what kept me here so long.
Nice physical environment (beautiful courtyard and break rooms).
Professional Development encouraged.
Excellent tuition reimbursement perks.
Annual raises.
cons:
The stress and demand of the job is harmful to your health.  I was one of soooooo many employees whose job stress lead to health issues.  Many people end up taking medical leave as a result.  I know people who experienced stress, anxiety, depression, seizures, ulcers, cancer, tumors, and complete mental breakdowns.  
Constant/regular mass layoffs.  You will always be in fear for your job.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: Met some awesome people. Co-workers make the day to day work almost enjoyable. Health plans were pretty decent. Free gym.
cons:
Yikes, where do I start? It's all about starts, starts, starts. Student that complete their first course. The company honestly does not care about the students. All they care about is making money, I mean, it's a for-profit school, but enrolling students that are nowhere near ready for school and strong arming them through their first class is borderline unethical. 

Leads are absolutely horrible. Most of the people we get on the phone are looking for certificate programs, jobs or have no idea why we are even talking.

At the end of the day, it's sales. Don't say "it's all about servicing our students" when that is a blatant lie.

review_title: stressful but it pays ok at the beginning
job_title: Enrollment Advisor in San Diego, CA
pros: You start off with decent pay, you do have room to move up in the company, it is a huge company that does fun company events.
cons: It is a sales position and you must enroll enough students. If you enroll enough students then you can get promoted and make a lot of money. If you don't you are fired or get a large paycut. These numbers aren't exact but from what I can see 2% move up in the company, 20% are fired, 50% receive pay cuts, and 28% get a pay increase. It is extremely high pressure and you are constantly reminded of the numbers.

job_title: Admissions Counselor in Clinton, IA
pros: I enjoyed helping people and the company on the whole facilitated that wish to help others, for the most part. Until they changed management in 2013.
cons: When they changed management in 2013 they started pulling away from their own "core values". One of which was that getting he student to graduate was our primary goal. The student is to come first, always. Help and support from the staff is key to earning a degree.

job_title: ESA in Denver, CO
pros: Pay and benefits are both good.  Solid 401(k) plan.  Awesome co-workers.
cons: Literally everything else.  Every level of management spews different lies to the people below them just to pretend like what they are doing actually helps people.  This is a for-profit online university that targets poor, uneducated people in the hopes that they can be tricked into spending over $12,000 per year for an education that probably won't help them in the first place.

job_title: Enrollment Advisor in Denver, CO
pros:
You will be surrounded by an awesome team and solid pay that isn’t based on commissions. 
The management style here is meant to better the individual at their job and give them the tools they need to succeed.
cons: This position can be a grind most days with calling cold leads in your database. This position is heavily focused on convincing and persuading people who don’t necessarily want a degree that they should go back to school. Therefore, if you are not the sales type or particularly fond of convincing someone against their will, this may not be the job for you.

job_title: Transfer Records Coordinator in Clinton, IA
pros:
Great people to work with. The majority of Online Center associates were young so the environment was exciting and fun. 
We were encouraged to be open and honest with our direct managers who you truly felt were on your team. 
We were given all tools need to do our jobs and were included in process improvement suggestions.
cons:
As a for-profit university you constantly felt that the end was close. At one point the school nearly lost accreditation. There were rounds of lay offs at which point I decided to leave the company. 
In the Registrar's department you never felt that you were doing anything shady but heard of issues coming from the admissions departments.

review_title: Ok if you don't mind dialing the same numbers everyday, 8 hours a day nonstop
job_title: Admissions Counselor in San Diego, CA
pros: Pay is decent for what you do ie dial dial dial all day long. There is nothing more to this job.
cons: If you actually have a college degree and you are doing this job, it makes you question is this what you went to college for... To dial numbers all day? Your manager will love you the day you enroll a student, and chew you out the next day if you don't. I actually don't believe in wht they sell.

job_title: Enrollment Advisor in San Diego, CA
pros: Good first job for college graduates who are comfortable in a competitive corporate culture. The starting pay and benefits are very competitive and as an employee, you are able to attend Ashford University on the company's dime.
cons: You are treated like sheep and expected to act like one. This is not the place for independent thinkers and those would like to be treated with respect and dignity. You have to check your dignity at the door. Management keeps you in the dark and lies to you more often than not.

review_title: Think of this job as a REALLY WELL paid internship.  Get your degree for free and get out.
job_title: Military Admissions Counselor in San Diego, CA
pros:
-Pay and benefits
-Fringe benefits like free tuition (If your manager likes you)
-Lots of free company sponsored events and outings.  They take care of their employees.
cons: Talking to students is great, finding them sucks!  Dream job if you didn't have to dial out of service numbers all day because you harass people to go to school until they finally disconnect their phones.

review_title: Changing / Unsure Culture and Overall Bad Environment
job_title: Admissions Counselor in Denver, CO
pros: Free education for those who are able to stay long enough to finish.
cons: Everything else.   The culture changed weekly and not for the better.  Sketchy managers and a leadership team who could not figure out who they wanted to be or how they wanted to run the company.

review_title: Good coworkers, good managers, poor upper management
job_title: NSLDS Specialist in Denver, CO
pros: Excellent training, work-life balance, diverse group of people
cons: Many class action lawsuits due to trying to grow to fast, saying anything to get new students in the door.  At one point they were planning to move HQ from CA to Denver, CO, then they had to contract by about 2/5, cut costs drastically.  Decisions were made, then executed poorly, then changed mid-stream.  Do not plan on growth or your job being around in 10 years, or maybe 5.

review_title: Good place for resume bad place to think of a career.
job_title: Admissions Counselor in Denver, CO
pros: The people! The people they hire are awesome, fun, outgoing, they make the job workable. The location, the Denver location is amazing on 16th street-lots of lunch places & happy hours. That you can get by hardly working.
cons: The place is churn and burn environment, if you are top you are untouchable if not get ready for unemployment. As a team lead and someone who always hit numbers I loved it, but the politics of upper management make the place a hot mess.

review_title: Ashford University is A Great School
job_title: University Advisor in San Diego, CA
pros: Great Benefits and Salary.  Highest starting salary in San Diego for sure. Free education, great work environment, no micro managing. Work hard and you get rewarded. All the people who write reviews saying Admissions counselors lie to students are lying themselves.  Employees who lie to students or do anything dishonest are walked out imediately. Students who are not eligible to go to school are denied admission period.
cons: Disgruntled employees who lie about the schools practices. Wasc accreditation is nerve wracking.  I don't want to move to Denver.

review_title: Eye opening... and up and down..
job_title: Admissions Counselor in San Diego, CA
pros: fun atmosphere, people are very nice, managers and directors are very kind, this is a great job if you are right out of college.. pays well for someone like this.. not hard work, just call and have conversations with people, throw balls around, listen to music, honestly, since the matrix was done away with.. it is rather enjoyable.  very good benefits, not a lot of stress (come on guys... if you think this is a stressful sales job.. try working in sales for over 10 years as i have.. you will know real stress and pressure, now that the matrix is gone, you need to bring in 1-3 students a week.  not hard to do.  trust me.. out in the real sales world.. bosses and managers are mean and want numbers and treat you like crap if you do not hit them.. this is kid's play here at AU.
cons:
the bad bad part of working there... at least for me as a very seasoned and successful sales person is no commission, no sales goals, no thrill of the kill etc.  doing the same thing day in and day out.  arghh.. boring.  plus, although everyone is nice, it is not the classiest place to work.  again, if you are a kid out of college.. great place to go, fun and nice people.  people with life and work experience.. well.. like me.. well it is killing me.  

also, there is a lot of unfair treatment by management.  favoritism.. feeding the ACs that are already making 85-105K students student apps already completed.. or ACs that they are grooming to become managers .. yet are not bringing in students.. feeding these folks apps that are basically already done.  here you go.  then the rest of us work our tails off and try to bring in a couple a week.  can take hours.  the managers tend to laugh and play around all day.

job_title: Admissions Counselor in San Diego, CA
pros: The people you work with on your team are probably the only good thing about being at Ashford. They're generally all great and helpful people.
cons: They are strictly numbers oriented with no consideration for the actual students you're enrolling. They don't care if the person is mentally unfit to be a student or has the IQ of a toddler, they just want their money from people you sign-up. The place will tell you different when you first begin working there and while you're in training but don't be fooled, if you're not producing enough students (regardless of how many qualified people you talk to) you'll soon be fired. The people we enroll often have no business even thinking about school. They are simply there to get a student loan check.

job_title: Core Faculty in London, England
pros: Work from home, decent pay, great colleagues.
cons: Management doesn't know what it's doing either in managing employees or in higher education.  Students get full credit for courses that have half the content of on-ground courses.  Schedules allow for almost no time off.  Expect to work 7 days a week.

review_title: Ashford University provides quality online Bachelors' degrees, but has little or no regard for employees.
job_title: Admissions Counselor in Chicago, IL
pros: The university provides employees with good insurance benefits. The facilities are clean and uniform, all cubicles are identical.  Most of the equipment furnished is new and up to date.
cons: Production is foremost requirement, contrary to mission statement. Employees are managed through fear of being fired. Management considers every employee as disposable and treats them as such. Very hostile work environment.

review_title: Online teaching- flexible but not good work-life balance
job_title: Teaching Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros: Instruction can be fully online and on a mostly flexible schedule, with weekly deadlines and some daily requirements. While it is text-only, you can add your own multimedia to make it more engaging and effective.
cons: If you have a day job M-F their schedule (T-Sun) can really mess up the week and you end up working 7 days a week. Recently their policies changed to increase Instructor load without a commensurate pay raise.

review_title: High turnover rate for employees and students
job_title: Enrollment Advisor in Hyderābād
pros: Tough to find something to fill this category but if you're an excellent sales person you'll make bank.
cons: No positions pay well unless you're in Admissions (Sales). If you're in Admissions (Sales), you will be quickly let go if you can't keep up with production. Retention does not seem to be a concern at Ashford for either employees or students.

job_title: Admissions Counselor in San Diego, CA
pros: Great Benefits, great pay, great mentors, great experience, good stepping stone.
cons: Challenges working there are calling the same database every single day. Over and over and over and over, until the person on the other line finally tells you to take them off the list and stop calling them.  Turnover, huge turnover. It's all about the numbers if you don't meet your numbers then you're tossed like last night's dinner. Despite the whole number thing you are given a warning ahead of time it's not a complete shock or anything.

job_title: Enrollment Advisor in Denver, CO
pros: Ashford University has great leadership and an extremely through training program. There's a high calibre of people that work there, which helps to foster the culture and fun environment.  As a plus, the education benefit allows you to obtain a degree virtually free.
cons: There's not enough higher level positions available for the large population of advisors to work towards. The University did away with annual raises,  but not annual performance evaluations. Without additional incentives,  it's hard to push toward high goals month by month.

job_title: Admissions Counselor in Denver, CO
pros:
Education reimbursement-100% tuition reimbursement up to a Masters, 80% for your spouse.

Pay- Pretty decent considering the work

Office- It's right downtown in a beautiful building, nicest cubicle maze I've ever seen.

Free Coffee- Need I say more?

Relaxed environment- It's a very young company, where you'll feel like your working with a bunch of college students. If that's what your going for, you'll enjoy it. 

Management- Although they can get on you very quickly, they're committed to helping you succeed and will provide the proper training.
cons:
Prospects- If you're coming from a B2B or professional sales environment, you're in for a doozy. Sadly, 95% of your prospective students are broke, unmotivated, uneducated and in some pretty terrible situations. Many times, you feel like a social worker first. Your lead database may average around 40% of DNC, not in service, wrong numbers and fax machines. Have fun!

Telemarketing- You will be making anywhere from 250-400 calls a day on average to the same numbers. Many days you'll come in with 1, maybe 2, new leads, so be prepared to work with peanuts. Since it's outbound to consumers, expect to be insulted and hung up on more times than not. 

Motivating without incentive- Coming from a traditional sales role, I'm used to the hunt for commissions, bonus. The thrill of the sale is special to me. That doesn't exist here. Since they're a college, they can't incentive. You'll be subject to daily motivational talks, pep rallies, energy drink giveaways to keep you excited, but since you're job is to contact prospects and get them enrolled (SALES), it's very tough to stay motivated. At one point, we were asked to enroll left and right for the reward of a "Good Job" poster the floor had. It's pathetic. 

Moral/Ethical concerns- First, it's a for profit college. You're mixing education and business, and it's never easy. There's an awful lot of bad press, as well as congressional reviews and audits around the industry. Additionally, as I mentioned with the prospects earlier, many of these students are in some pretty scary situations. Is it right to throw someone into a $30K student loan repayment with the promise that their degree will "change their life" when they can barely afford food? Is it right to try to pitch the school to others already enrolled elsewhere? Shoot, did I get a 4 year degree for $X amount to be a telemarket?

review_title: And then the other shoe dropped
job_title: Admissions Counselor in San Diego, CA
pros: The pay was great, I was able to actually change lives for the better, I met and worked with some truly amazing and inspiring individuals
cons: Management does not all operate on the same page. Policies change easily without notice to employees. There is very little recognition for the hard work people put in unless numbers go along with it.

job_title: Admissions Counselor in San Diego, CA
pros:
You can potentially get your undergraduate or Masters Degree tuition free.  

Good people in the Admissions Role, can meet lots of people very quickly.

Good starting benefits if you take advantage of them.  401k , Health, Sick, ext... but if you don't use it you don't have it!

Great way to learn a new CRM system and understand your numbers / conversions; great tools for that. 

Can advance, from Admissions Counselor to Manager to Director or University Advisory. 

Company does a good job training its sales reps on and off the floor. 

You'll always have a story to vent to your significant other at the end of everyday. 

Continuous learning on the job.
cons:
Not a lot of job security, company has mass firings and hiring periods without warning. 

Micro Management to the fullest! You come back from your break 1 minute late its the end of the world for them, but it all depends on your manager. I had 5 since I started, they come and they go. 

Most admission people / employees are scared. Lots of changes all the time, sometimes for the good, mostly for the bad. 

You have to work their roughly 6* months before you can begin your degree, must be approved by both manager and director. Sometimes depending on your manager they do not approve it or take it away from you while you are in the program. Must be meeting "expectations" which is student enrollment but they will not say that becasue its a gray area... You can get stuck paying the tuition or if you get fired or leave the company you might not have finished your program. 

Lots of pressure from management and directors to be meeting numbers. There are no breaks even if you are exceeding expectations, the more they see you can produce the more they will try to get out of you. 

Many people are overweight, probably becasue of stress and micromanaging. We have a term its called the Ashford 15 lbs!  

Sometimes the managers and directors do not know how to implement the changes effectively and positively so there is always insecure employees and unnecessary business disruptions which is put on YOU. 

There is no commission, the harder you work no "real reward" unless you take advantage of the tuition free degree, people next to you might not be meeting numbers and the pressure gets put on you to carry their weight. You feel it from your managers or directors everyday. 

Company is for profit and they are definitely cutting or trying to make creative ways to cut costs / benefits for their employees. For example paying a lot less for manager position and university advisers than before. Increasing Health Care Costs, Paying new employees less, letting go of senior employees who make more without warning.

review_title: A great place to work and learn!
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros:
-This is a great place to work if you'd like to further your own education. The bachelors, masters, and even phd tuition assistance program is awesome.
-You get to help others fulfill their dream of an education.
-This is a fast-paced, ever-changing place (i.e., you won't be bored!).
-The employees in San Diego have an on-site medical clinic. This is very handy.
-It's hard to beat the pay and benefits.
-If you're interested in starting a management career, there are plenty of opportunities to move up.
cons: -Can't think of any that would dissuade me from staying here.

job_title: Enrollment Advisor in Denver, CO
pros:
-Ok pay
-Good coworkers (because misery loves company)
    -BUT, you will be working against your coworkers, not with them
cons:
-Management that looks for any reason to fire you
-turnover of about 6 months (don't accept a job here unless you know it's temporary)
-None, if you can live with the immoral work of screwing over those with no money
   -Don't let anyone fool you, it is cold calling the uneducated and gullible to have them take out maximum loans, still not have enough to finish without going out of pocket, and those that do are left with a degree that is useful as toilet paper if they print it out themselves. I tried really hard to see the good in what I was doing, but the numbers don't add up. It's a leeching business first and a college never. Everyone should have the opportunity to go to college, but here they just harrass the student by calling them everyday and leave them off no better than when they started, but much more in debt
DO YOUR RESEARCH BEFORE ACCEPTING A JOB HERE
  I believe strongly in higher education, but Ashford is here to take advantage of loans and grants. I originally came on here because Ashford told me to write them a good review, but I want to save anyone from making the same mistake I did.
-No chance of movement anywhere (real colleges wont care about your for profit experience and they only hire from the outside)
-Run by fear of losing jobs with no incentive for doing well

job_title: Admissions Counselor in San Diego, CA

cons:

job_title: Admissions Counselor in San Diego, CA

Management adjusts school ploicy and operations to maximize their compensation rather than to improve service quality and student experience.

job_title: Admissions Counselor in Denver, CO

job_title: Project Manager in San Diego, CA
pros:
Wonderful people to work with! 
Great benefits! New benefits this year to enhance employee satisfaction!
Moving in the right direction! 
Supports our students!
Great recognition for work well done! 
Live work balance! I don't take my work home with me!
cons:
Currently there is a low chance of moving up in the organization.

job_title: Enrollment Services Manager in Denver, CO
pros: Denver leadership was amazing. It was an honor to work with a collaborative group that cared about what their employees thought. I will always be in debt to my superiors for taking the time to mentor me in my role which gave me greater confidence to develop my employees.
cons: I enjoyed my tenure with Ashford University, please keep the focus on culture and employee engagement. I believe the Denver location truly is a great place to work. Thank you JL & LP for the years of encouragement.

review_title: Fires Talent Because Something is Wrong
job_title: Admissions Counselor in San Diego, CA
pros: This work place is full of people with incredible personalities and identities. You won't survive here unless you have that. That being said -some of the best relationships I've had  were from this place. People are interesting and fun. Compensation is competitive and benefits are good. There is a gym and cafeteria on location. As long as you can enroll and retain the students you are good.
cons: As long as you can enroll and retain students you are good. The problem with this sentence is that it is very hard to not stay on the roller coaster. Meaning, you will do well you will be busy enrolling but once you spend time with your current students your prospecting time goes down and you stop enrolling. It's seriously a viscous circle. Very talented people get fired all of time here. I like to say Ashford has hired and fired half of San Diego. They'll get it right one day.

job_title: Admissions Counselor in San Diego, CA
pros: It was a very competitive place to work and they offer great insurance, 401 (k), etc.
cons: Very hard to always hit your goals.  They want you to get outside referrals but you are not allowed to advertise in any way.

job_title: Admissions Counselor in San Diego, CA
pros: Decent pay, diverse environment. I thought the benefits were good, but people with dependents thought different. Seriously that's all the pros I can think of, the environment became really toxic.
cons: The company instills fear of losing your job as motivation. They have cut starting pay for incoming counselors. Layoffs, which the company lists as an official "dismissal" on your employment record, happens twice a year.

review_title: Spend the bulk of your work life making a corporation money!
job_title: Enrollment Advisor in Denver, CO
pros:
Good hourly pay, until you consider how much money you're getting paid compared to the amount of business you're closing.
Fast paced sales environment, which can be extremely motivating if you are made for that.
Eco pass
HR department at least seems human
cons:
This corporate kingdom rules their employees by fear-you will be constantly reminded of all the things that could cost you your job, such as being more than five minutes late (or is it 1 minute? Three minutes? This will change depending on whatever mood your trainer is in at the time) to a training session more than three times over a three week period, not hitting a CT (talk time) percentage high enough to be considered "valuable" (this number changes daily, often at your managers whim), or wearing something your manager doesn't like/eating something your manager finds disgusting/not being sexually appealing to your manager so you will not get attention/breathing.
 
Management is unskilled to manage sales staff and motivates their workers through threats and bullying.  They go for immediate results so they can look good to their superiors and don't have the necessary training or acumen to manage a real sales staff. Of course, they aren't managing a sales staff, are they? It's a staff of "enrollment services advisors". 

As you can tell, this company lies to people.  I imagine it only gets worse the higher up the chain you go.  I can't even imagine what sorts of lies are told to the client. 
  
Loud, gossip-ridden work environment.

All about numbers and sales at the end of the day, but they are not honest about how much that will be your focus during the hiring process. This causes a LOT of turnover once people find out the truth. 

Shady company with a shady past.

job_title: Admissions Counselor in San Diego, CA
pros: Decent pay and awesome cafeteria.
cons:
The pros: The pay is very decent, and the cafteria is awesome. Now...

The cons: When applying for this job they never mention the word SALES. They say you're being hired as a "Admissions Counselor" but in reality you're selling people on going to school, and you're doing so by making cold calls ALLLLL DAY long. Even in training they say things like "give them the vision, etc...". Still never saying the word sale. After about a month I revealed to HR that I was pregnant, and was coinsidentally fired the very next day for having been 3 minutes late 3 weeks prior due to an accident on the freeway that I verified and passing training with 100%.
JUST A HORRIBLE AND STRESSFUL PLACE TO WORK UNLESS YOU'RE INTO SALES.

job_title: University Advisor in San Diego, CA
pros: Great experience helping others achieve their lifelong goal of completing their college education!  Excellent opportunities for upward mobility, significantly improve one's sales skills, develop greater relationship building skills with students, and my education was paid for.
cons: From my perspective, there was not a consistency with the management team.  In other words I worked for many different managers during my career there.  Also, toward the end of my career I did not feel stable in my position due to the financial stability of the company.

job_title: Admissions Counselor in San Diego, CA
pros:
* Great Pay and Benefits - you are paid hourly, which is great when overtime is offered. Also, you get every Federal Holiday as a paid day off.

* Perks - The company offers some discounts at local events (i.e. Padres games) and hosts special events for employees (i.e. Wild Animal Park company picnic)

* Work Environment - the Sunroad and Evening Creek buildings are fairly new, provide roomy cubices, and have good snack and lunch options in the cafes (Evening Creek is much better than Sunroad, however)

* Diversity - fellow employees range in age, with the majority being 20-30 yrs old, but there are some older employees as well
cons:
*Young Management - fellow employees range in age, with the majority being 22-30 yrs old. However if you are over 26 yrs of age, expect your manager and their supervisor to be younger than you. This can be extremely frustrating, as there is a lack of management experience company-wide, and many managers were promoted before they were ready. As a new employee, if you are assigned to one of the aforementioned managers, your success will be nearly impossible unless you are willing to do an obscene amount of brown-nosing and network with the right people to learn the ins and outs on your own.

*Telemarketing - In the interviews and training they say you will get "warm leads", but the truth is the numbers you call to find prospective students were bought by the company and are very cold leads.  Nine times out of ten, they were job hunting online and accidentally entered their info, but they are not interested in going to school. The Admissions Counselor job is a sales job, and you will need to leave your conscience and morals at the door in order to succeed. If the person you are talking to is unemployed and has no way to pay off the loans, you are expected to ignore that and talk them into going to school, whether or not it is really the best thing for them. The ones who succeed in this position aren't the brightest employees there, they are the sharks or the ones who are too dim to realize that what they are doing is wrong.

*Repetitive and Dull - Being a telemarketing position, you will spend 90% of your day dialing numbers and listening to ringtones. If you actually get someone on the phone, they will usually hang up on you once they hear where you are calling from. The managers keep track of the call logs, so they will know how much you are dialing and what your talk time is, so there is pressure to dial 300-400 numbers a day if you aren't talking to enough people.

*Advancement is Unlikely - Yes, there is room for advancement in the company, but you are not likely to be one of the chosen few. Timing is everything, so if you happen to have the experience and the numbers at the right time, you might get promoted, but it will take years and a lot of shameless brown-nosing. You need to be your manager's favorite to get noticed, which means you need to have the most students out of your whole team, and keep it that way every week. And you need to find your inner cheerleader and spout Ashford University propaganda every chance you get so you fit in with the higher-ups. Easy enough if you have no pride or mind of your own.

*Parking and Elevator Congestion - You do not have any promise of a parking spot. Expect to arrive at least 30 min early in order to maybe get a parking spot. Otherwise, expect to park blocks away from the building. And if you want to go out to lunch, realize you risk not finding a parking spot when you return and most likely being late. Also, factor in extra time for the elevator line. In the morning and after lunch, you will need at least 10-15 minutes to wait in line for the elevator. And if you want to go downstairs to grab a snack on your break, you will spend 10 of your 15 minutes dealing with the elevator situation . Oh, and at the end of the day, you will spend up to 20 minutes trying to get on the elevator to leave, and another 15 minutes stuck in traffic out of the parking lot. When you add up the time spent each day on these issues, it gets extremely frustrating.

*Numbers are Everything - And finally, if all of the above hasn't gotten to you and you have a great attitude, they will still fire you if you haven't enrolled enough students. They are constantly analyzing your numbers, and no matter how great you are, that is all they care about at the end of the day. If you are a superb salesperson, you can be successful here. For the rest of you, beware. This is not a counseling job, you are not saving the world, it is sales, sales, sales. Leave your morals at the door, and you just might like it here.

review_title: Good pay and benefits, hard to stick around.
job_title: Admissions Counselor in San Diego, CA
pros: Your experience really depends on your manager.  Mine was great.  They have changed their on-boarding process significantly in order to better prepare new hires for the job.  Extremely difficult but rewarding at times.
cons: Difficult job. High pressure sales environment.  If you and your manager don't click, it's absolutely miserable from what I've seen.  Even if you do get along great, not meeting the numbers puts a lot of pressure on everyone associated with you.

job_title: Student Advisor in San Diego, CA
pros: Benefits are ok, pay is ok, and they have a good coffee cart. You will make friends. I'd call this an ok first job if you're planning to move in within a year or 2. But definitely move on.
cons:
Literally everything else. It's like working at Innotech from Office Space. 
 
Ethics: make no mistake, you work for a corporation. This isn't just for-profit education, it's public ally traded. Every company decision is made with a bottom line mindset first, putting the share holders and the stock value above students and employees. The place gradually got worse and worse and more and more cruel thought my 5 years there. Additionally, it's expensive and the quality of the education is sorely lacking. Your students will have trouble putting together whole sentences, much less a professional communication.
The job: call center customer service. Your priority is to be a phone jockey and to re enroll dropouts. It's somewhere between hotline and sales, and you will be told to put quantity before quality. You'll be reminded you're a small cog in a big indifferent machine. You are not heard, your voice means nothing, and if it seems otherwise they're just shining you on. I worked there 5 years and no one ever made a real difference. They used to ask our opinions about improving the workplace in anonymous surveys. They stopped doing that. 
Benefits/perks: gradually waning, with no end in sight. I'd love to mention the free education, but I can't say it's even worth taking advantage of. But sometimes they bring in cold Little Cesar's, so there's that. 
Community: literally everyone I knew there had made a hobby of trying to find another job. It dominates the morale, of which there is little. It feels like they are always shrinking departments (including maintenance and IT) which is discouraging. 
Facility: oof. There are nice things about the building but they've really started cutting costs, so you'll have large chunks of time where things in bathrooms and break rooms aren't replenished at all. The cafeteria is a ripoff. Parking is frustrating. The printers and elevators break down weekly, no exaggeration.

job_title: Enrollment Services Advisor in Denver, CO
pros:
Pay is decent for entry level position.
Employee's are cool, but upper management and floor directors are poooh!
Decent location in the middle of downtown Denver.
cons:
Atmosphere is depressing, no one likes working here!
You leave voicemails all day, leads are so recycled and no one answers for toll free numbers.
All about numbers, they trick you and tell you its not a sales position in training, but it is soo sales, just not commission based because of school and board of education. 
Cubicle style set up.
Way overpopulated.

review_title: Fun place to work, but limited opportunities
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Denver, CO
pros:

The overall culture in the Denver office is very supportive, and it's a fun place to work. I really enjoy working with my manager and teammates.
cons: There are salary limitations for each position, and due to federal regulations, any student-facing positions are ineligible for bonuses based on performance. There are also limited options for promotion or job transfer.

job_title: Admissions Counselor in San Diego, CA

Promotions are limited.  A lot of growth in the sense of new employees in various areas, but seems to be due to people quiting or being fired.

job_title: University Advisor in San Diego, CA

cons: Training does not give a clear picture of what the job really is. High end phone sweat shop.

job_title: College Advisor in San Diego, CA
pros: Ashford is a good starter job.  Employees are allowed flexible schedules.  There are excellent educational benefits.  The faculty at Ashford University collaborates well with other departments.  The atmosphere at work is fun and employees work together well to help students.
cons: Ashford is still growing and working to establish its niche in a highly competitive market.  There is room for improvement in how Ashford uses information and Ashford's adaptability to an quickly change landscape.  There employee development structure is lacking.

job_title: in San Diego, CA
pros: I was able to gain experience in a niche education field. Online education seems to offer some career growth opportunities in certain positions.  Additionally, I was able to earn my graduate degree through the University for free.
cons: Leadership seems misdirected.  They were always open to new ideas from the folks that were working on the floor.  However, they would proceed with projects that would impact multiple stakeholders including students without fully researching the idea.

job_title: Admissions Counselor in Denver, CO

I left a management job to take a job at Ashford University in Colorado and was unhappy pretty much from the first moment I started dealing with the actual job I was doing. I feel they misrepresented it to me.

review_title: Best Learning Experience---what not to do!!
job_title: Student Relations Specialist in San Diego, CA
pros:
*Great benefits package with vacation/sick/holidays; they offer overtime frequently
*Nice building
*Energetic work environment with gym and cafe
*Free tuition if you want to attend school there
*There are lot of employees who do care and are there to help students succeed that would never have had the chance otherwise
*Great learning experience on what not to do, and how not to manage
cons:
*Admissions is a complete sales job.  It is stressful, with lots of high pressure and you are NEVER good enough.  It is not about the student, it is about the number for the day.  Honestly, this is education, not sales!
*Pressure you into working weekends  when it is unnecessary 
*Zero communication skills---they never tell you what is going on and then the next day, everything may be different in your department and they expect you to just "embrace change"
*They do not value their employees and everyone feels extremely disposable
*If one is "producing" they can get away with almost anything.  I have seen the most unethical workers keep their jobs because they were enrolling students like crazy (the students end up dropping and are left with a huge bill they cannot pay)

I hate writing reviews like this because normally I am such a positive person.  The way this company is run is so frustrating that I needed to speak the truth.

job_title: Admissions Counselor in Denver, CO
pros: Starting salary is competitive and it's an easy environment to build relationships with co-workers.
cons: No job security (there were multiple massive layoffs during my stint there), shady lead generation practices, promotion are often based more on popularity than merit, most of your day is spent convincing lower-income people to take out financial aide loans for an education that most don't complete at a school whose accreditation is up in the air.

job_title: Admissions Counselor in San Diego, CA
pros: Extremely well trained/prepared for the job. I really liked the vibe on the floor, and most employees got along with each other well. Some of the older reps, however, who benefited from old ED regulations and who made substantially more, had an arrogance that was not cool.
cons: Bullpen environment at times...not a clear path for promotion. The opportunity to participate in leadership development programs is based on interviews and eligibility criteria. One can meet the criteria, but not get much of an interview (the list of those accepted was known prior to the actual interview).

review_title: The real deal for the Enrollment Services Advisor position
job_title: Enrollment Services Advisor in San Diego, CA
pros:
Real deal about PROS:

**Fun environment (if you like music and noise)
**Networking events
**Change peoples lives (help people find careers instead of jobs)
**Lots of goodies (foods, snacks,etc)
**Training's
**Team building exercises

**Benefits

Here's the reality of the role:

**high turn over (in my tenure of 15mos, I had 6 different managers)
**stressful if you're not having student complete their first course
**depending on the team(people are negative)
**quality of students
**don't have a say in changing positions or teams
**constantly changing teams (because of turnover)
**constantly changing desk

review_title: Don't be an advisor if you don't like sales
job_title: Enrollment Services Advisor in San Diego, CA

I had a manager tell us he would be micromanaging us from then on. He wasn't kidding. They make a fuss about "life changes" but when it comes down to it it's all about numbers.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA

review_title: It is a sales job but they don't tell you that.

review_title: It is a sales job with high turnover
job_title: Admissions Counselor in San Diego, CA

review_title: It is a high-volume, phone sales environment, but they can't say that.
job_title: Admissions Counselor in San Diego, CA

They are trying to avoid the sales stigma in their new job descriptions to avoid losing federal funding, but nothing will change because the company is profit driven.

job_title: Student Services Coordinator in San Diego, CA

review_title: Great place to meet people. High pressure sales environment.
job_title: Student Advisor in San Diego, CA
pros: Some great co-workers and even a few really good managers.
cons: Subtle high pressure sales environment that is advertised as a real advisor role. The truth is you are only there to push low interest or qualification prospects into any degree program in order to retain them long enoug to collect financial aid funds for low quality online courses.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros:
This place is now under Bridgeport Education. I did alright there for a little more than a year. Meaning I hit my "Expectations" every month. I gained some very good experience understanding a business and looking at numbers. I personally didn't like selling education because to me, Sales and Education do not and should not go together and by the end of everything, I checked out and resigned because i didn't believe in what I was doing. There's a lot of shady schools out there that really rip off students (Everest College), but Ashford tries hard not to be.

- Pay and benefits are decent for working for a "school".
- The people you would work with become family to you and makes the days/job so much better
- The training is top notch if you are trying to learn some sales skills and techniques.
- There's technically a 6 month grace period to see if this would be a good fit for you before they start cracking the whip on your numbers. They just don't tell you that
- A great and positive attitude will get you far here.
- Free education after working there for 6 months.
- Most affordable for-profit online schools (decent product).
- Partnered up with Forbes for the business school. Pretty cool.
cons:
-With the Board of Education, having a quota or productivity based performance for employees to meet is against the law. Ashford still has "expectations" where you HAVE to get minimum 3 active students and 5 applications for one month (unless its a longer month then its 4 active/7 applications). 

-It's a manipulation and persuasion tactic they train you on in order to get people to enroll with the school. They say you're "changing lives" (which can happen when the consumer does well and stays in school so thats rewarding), but it's their way to make you motivated to sell and its super cheesy and comes off fake. 

-The school just settled a lawsuit for being accused of using "unconscionable or coercive tactics' to encourage students to enroll." They're also under investigation for violating the Telephone Consumer Protection Act. 

-They're trying to be on the list of the best places to work. Not going to happen while they still have a high turnover rate and they also do big firings about every 6 months if you are not hitting your "expectations". They can afford this because they have new training cohorts coming in about every two months.

-Heavily and uncomfortably micromamaged. They make you use a system that calculates your work performance every day and if you're not hitting those minimum daily explications (% of time on the phone - aka connect time and % of time in utilization - aka doing your job efficeintely) then be prepared to answer to your manager as to why your phone calls are not long enough or you're not dialing enough. Your phone calls are also recorded and listened to assure compliance and be used for coaching purposes.

-You will work for Big Brother and are watched by the Thought Police. They see all, They hear all. 

-Lastly, your private "business" numbers are there for everyone to see. If you're not doing well at times, you can feel a little embarrassed when you have to discuss your monthly progress and numbers in front of your Manager, Team, and Director.

job_title: Associate Faculty (Online) in Clinton, IA

This cannot be your main source of income.  Few students are college ready; lots of plagiarism due to coursework posted online for sale.  Discussion board topics are generally boring, resulting in poor critical thinking from students.  I finally was disgusted enough that I quit after 4+ years.

review_title: It was fun while it lasted
job_title: Admissions Counselor in San Diego, CA
pros:

job_title: Enrollment Services Advisor in San Diego, CA
pros: The pay rate is quite high for a beginning salary for such a lowbrow job.
cons:
Ashford University is a scam. Employees are directed to focus on sales and boosting the university's numbers (read: quantity, not quality); Advisors work in very loud work environments (teams on each floor are encouraged to ring bells, cheer, chant, and play music at all levels to compete with surrounding teams); Employees are directed to call the same phone numbers up to three times per day (this is a cold-call center, although employers will try to have you believe these are "warm" calls); Neither Ashford nor Bridgepoint Education, Ashford's parent company, is interested in the quality of the students' education, as depicted by the high student drop-out rate and high employee turnover; Ashford exploits students who rely on federal student aid (general loans, veteran grants, and loans for disability), especially those who are easily tricked and have backgrounds with little schooling; Advisors will push potential students to apply in the first phone call; Advisors will use any trick to keep individuals on the phone, including lying and fabricating stories that may resonate with the individuals; Managers and directors assess each advisor’s hours by recording and calculating how the advisor delegates every minute during the working day (time spent on the phone, number of phones calls per day, and hours “away”, including time spent in the bathroom).

You can get by in an Enrollment Services Advisor position at Ashford University for a few months by doing nearly nothing (or by making positive changes to alert callers/customers/students of Ashford’s façade and of the individual’s rights as a customer), but it will catch up to you. I took the job at Ashford because I was desperate, they paid a decent amount for a starting salary, and the position was seemingly in an area in which I had interest and experience. I wasn’t naive to the fact that this was a call center where morals might be questionable, I was just desperate for a job and I had some sliver of hope that I might make a positive difference.

I did the best that I could to inform individuals of their right to ask us to stop calling (which, by law, requires the caller to stop if there is no business and/or monetary agreement between the two). Without Ashford’s encouragement or approval, I created my own English and computer lessons for a student who should not have been admitted into the school to begin with, who should have, instead, taken remedial classes to understand the basic concepts of certain subjects. (For example, this student did not know how to turn on her computer or how to write a complete sentence.) I’m a huge proponent for continued education, but only with steps that are helpful and which give the student a foundation on which to grow, steps which Ashford does not provide.

The micromanagement and threats to terminate employees further prove Ashford’s lack of trust in its employees, but what ultimately led me to quit was the deception that Ashford sells to uninformed students.

Currently, there’s approximately a $24 million lawsuit against Ashford University for deceiving students into believing that financial loans would not be nearly as expensive as they actually are after students leave or graduate. This lawsuit follows a $7.25 million lawsuit in 2014, where Ashford graduates who studied education were not recognized by their home state as qualified teachers.

job_title: Instructor in San Diego, CA
pros: Some nice students and clear structure and advice. Good response times from the help person assigned to faculty.
cons:
Welcome to the McDonaldization of teaching. Very little control. 
After several classes with good student reviews, I was basically not reassigned when the chair offered "coaching" and I asked if it was evaluative and voluntary or not. Asking this question ultimately got me no more classes. The "coaching" consisted of being told to cut and paste reponses with ther person's name in every one, irrespective of when it made sense to offer feedback. It was also pressure to perform much more labor for the same paycheck with zero insight from the instructor. You can bet the feedback I got from the "coach" was the same type they were advocating: cut and pasted suggestions for improvement. Even before the pressure to do more unpaid academic labor, the pay is about what you'd make at McDonalds. No dialog allowed on what constitutes good teaching, and actually no good teaching required. Just give everyone perfect scores or the professor is required to explain every point deducted from the student, they do not have to earn points. you earn the right to deduct points. the majority of students did need assistance and were not writing at a college level. in every course, there was at least one person found to be plagiarizing to the level of needing to be reported. this can be challenging because to truly offer a worthwhile educational experience, addressing these issues is time consuming. students rated my courses highly and made comments indicating the instruction was good. the coach rated me as "distinguished" in all but one category where they said I was under for not cutting and pasting enough pat responses and 100% repeating the students name in every commment so as soon as the course was over, I was told there weren't any classes available. within a month, they'd deleted my account entirely. I was already struggling with whether for-profit schools with cookie cutter classes were ethical. this left a bad taste in my mouth for sure.

Making dials at your desk all day isn’t for everyone

review_title: Check your morals, integrity and self-respect at the door.
job_title: Admissions Counselor in San Diego, CA
pros: The pay is decent and the company has good benefits. Major holidays off with pay and has a pretty liberal dress code.
cons:
As I said in the title, you really must check your integrity and morals at the door. I want to preface this by saying its not like I was in for a shock when I hit the floor and was dialing upwards of 300 numbers a day.  They emphasize in their interview process and I acknowleded I  understood this would be the case. I also was told to expect to be hung up on and cursed at while on the job. Got it-and I did not take that part personally while on the job. However, In this position, I was making hundreds of calls daily to students who made it more than abundantly clear they were not interested in attending college.  It's ironic because in the training manual we receive it states that we are not to call students excessively.  They never give a number to the word 'excessively", but I can tell you in my case I was expected to call new leads  3 to 4 sometimes even 5 times a day!  Does that seem excessive?  I doubt if collection agencies phone their clients that often.
This is a numbers driven game; while I was there, I actually produced a decent number of enrollments and had never been talked to or disciplined for a lack of productivity. As far as the numbers driven part, they will tell you the opposite, that AU is about the student and changing their lives for the better.  Selling them the idea that their lives will be so much better in four years when they attain their Bachelors degree.  I honestly beleived that I would be in the business of helping people.  Not so much.  Enrollments and how many you can attain in the week is the name of the game.  One day when my manager was particularly frustrated at us actually told us 'you can pretend its not a numbers driven game all you want, but it is!'  I was instructed that in the course of talking to a prospective student, if they in any way indicated they may have a prior default on a loan to end the call as soon as posssible-"dont' waste your time on them."  I was made to call individuals who had previously, explicitely stated 'take me off of your call list'.  Talking indigent students--people who could barely put food on the table, people who could not even afford their own computer--into a $50,000 online education is, in my opinion unethical and unconscionable.  
In addition, my experience with management was dismal.  Poor, inadequete coaching and teaching methods was what I endured throughout my tenure there.
I really could go on with specific stories of unethical, hostile, intimidating stories of what I and others experienced there, but it would take up too much space here.  I'll end with this--I really did make a decent wage there and had excellent benefits--those things could not even come close to making up for the sick sinking feeling I had everyday while on their 'sales' floor.  Many times I could not shake it even after I got home--I made the decision to leave.
