review_title: Do not apply at this university -- lousy pay and worse treatment.
job_title: Instructor, College Or University in Cheyenne, WY
pros: I got classes regularly, and I enjoyed the students.
cons: Where to begin?  (1) one of lowest paying online colleges, (2) lousy, biased curriculum, (3) horrific management, for starters.  I taught part time for about four years.  The pay was lousy and the courses sub-par, but I kept teaching because I had regular assignments and I enjoyed the students.  I had been doing pretty much the same thing my entire time there, always with good evaluations, and then late last year I got hammered on my evaluation out of the blue.  At the time I was in the middle of one class and had another assigned, so even though the eval was ridiculous and the changes that were demanded of me were way out of line (especially, as I said, considering the lousy pay) I made the changes in the middle of the class I was teaching, and incorporated them into the next class when it started.  I don't even want to calculate what my hourly rate was given the pay and the demands on my time.  When the second class ended, I had no further offerings.  I figured enrollment numbers were down and a class would come, given that I had rarely gone more than a week or two between starts.  Two months later, there was still no offering, so I emailed the individual in charge of making course assignments, as well as the office that oversaw them to see if maybe I had missed some mandatory training.  No answer whatsoever.  Another month later and I receive an email in my personal email saying they no longer required my services.  No explanation, no consideration that I altered what I was doing to meet all of the demands from my evaluation (despite my better judgment), no opportunity for improvement.  Just silence, an email, and then my account disabled, after four years of teaching.  I would never go back and never encourage another to teach there.

review_title: Most unhappy I've ever been in my whole life...
job_title: Enrollment Advisor in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Pros- the friendships I've made with some very special people.
cons:
Everything-
Sales quota to meet weekly in enrolling students
Pay and reviews are simply based off of those numbers alone, and not the quality of support or help that one offers to their students
Substantial paycuts if you are unable to meet your sales goals, I've specifically heard of up to 20K
You can only move up if you're friends with HR or a Manager who is related to the Director
I feel like the most incompetent employee ever, degraded on a daily basis as to why I am so incompetent and cannot enroll more "bodies" even though I know it would not be in the best interest of the student
It's always my fault if a student is in default or overlapping loan period so that I cannot enroll them at this time
Overtime and weekends are required if you want to make any progress whatsoever, so that we are forced away from our families and children
If you're sick on any given day, be sure that your entire database will be perused though by your fellow "teammates"
One for one, and who you may consider your friend today will tomorrow cut you at the knees to get that next student enrolled, because it helps them towards potentially getting a pay increase

Since when was college education such a cut throat business, hurting everyone else including the student just so that you can "be on top"?

job_title: Financial Services Operations Lead in Clinton, IA
pros: Benefits (Tuition fully paid for, there are "decent" medical benefits, convenience.
cons: Constant fear of layoffs, lawsuits, job loss and DOE reviews. Restrictions on growth.

job_title: Admissions Counselor in San Diego, CA
pros: The people were great. The food trucks outside were good, an hour for lunch break, in house gym was cool, good pay
cons: It is a about numbers and they treat people like numbers, not people. You will be micromanaged by the second.

job_title: Enrollment Advisor in San Diego, CA
pros: Starting salary is actually pretty good for an entry level job.  If you are a college grad you can expect to earn $40k to start with decent benefits.  This is attractive to young employees who really haven't done anything in their lives except party in San Diego's gaslamp quarter and take selfies in the bathroom . There is a gym onsite for those .. i guess that's a pro.  Only problem is the is locker room room is small so in the morning you have all these muscle heads taking up space in the first floor bathroom. The building on spectrum Center is a nice building with great views.  The benefits are decent as well especially if you are single and have no dependants.
cons:
Unlike the pros I will list the cons in list form.
1. Very young work force.  Feel like i am going to a club downtown.  People are always trying to hook up with each other.

2. Very stressful. It is hard enough to enroll as student who doesn't really want to enroll and who does not have the intellectual capacity to even making it to the first class.

3. You are expected not only to enroll your student but basically strong arm them to complete their first class.. walking them almost hand in hand in how to get their homework done.  I swear my young daughter who is 3rd grade needs less coaxing to go to school.  Every week they go over a report of how your students are progressing by going over what assignments they have or have not completed along with their current grade etc.  This is all because the student pool that Ashford gets via leads they buy or referrals are not even remotely interested in school.  Managers say the student enrolls because of you(advisor) not the school. With that comment you basically downplayed the value of your school and based it instead on the likeability of the advisor .

4. Middle management is full of themselves.  They throw around the fact that they rec'd a masters degree , yet the job they are in doesn't even require a degree.  You have a masters degree and you are training coach.  Come on aim higher.

5. Lets go over again the pool of potential students.  The potential student pool consist of recovering addicts and unemployed just to name a few.  Although not stated , Ashford actively recruits African American students, which is great , however they also have the lowest graduation rates.  You as an advisor are basically expected to convince the student that they should go to college .. take out loans knowing full well that only 20% will ever finish.

6. When you are new you are assigned a leads database that are 3 years old.  They have been called literally everyday 3x a day over the last year.  The prospect has stated not interested or I am going to school or I am terminally ill at least 10x yet they continue to harass and call them until they say take me off your call list.

job_title: Enrollment Advisor in Chicago, IL
pros: Pay. The recruiters will recruit you and tell you a bunch of lies to make this sound like the best job by offering you a high salary. The ONLY good thing about this job was the pay. However, no amount of pay is worth how awful this job is.
cons:
Everything, no matter of pay is worth taking this job, don't do it. They will tell you you get to work from home 2 days a week, make around 50-80 calls a day, get incoming hot leads and call off a current and great database of leads. They also will tell you you can make your own schedule and you have a "managerial level" job so you won't be micro managed. All of this could not be further from the truth! Reality is, you are required to make about 300 outgoing phone calls a day to leads that are expired, outdated and not legit. Maybe 1 in 10 calls you will reach a live person who says "STOP calling Me, your company calls me about 5 times a day, every day". The reason being is they hand out call lists and literally all the advisers call the same contacts several times a day until they reach a live person. The only way you get incoming calls is if you achieve high student enrollment, catch, the only way you can do this is by having a good lead list which does not exist. Basically advisers learned the tricks, you just dial 250-300 numbers a day off these sheets to get it to appear you have tried really hard to find students, this will save you your job for a week or two. They monitor EVERY call, your every move and it couldn't be more micro managed of an environment, very far from the truth the recruiters will tell you. They also will give you the crappy hours that nobody wants until you are there for a year or so. You can't make your own hours as the recruiters said. They will also rip you apart, pulling you randomly into the office and asking you what you do for your every 30 minute schedule, for example "Why did you only make 2 calls in 30 minutes? Why did this call only last 10 seconds? Why didn't you call this person back after they said they were not interested, maybe they were just at work and said that because they couldn't talk" The directors will hound you and criticize you over anything and everything, literally. 

Don't leave your job to work here, it will be the biggest mistake you ever made. Also note, you are not allowed to interview with the person will you actually report to, take this as another sign. I wish I did. The reviews are really bad about accreditation and the statistics are you need to have about 1000 calls to just get 1 student at this company.  They are on notice and why would a student enroll here with all the bad press? Don't do it, trust me.

There is high turn over at this place for a reason, it's just a terrible job making 300 calls a day to leads that are outdated and not legit people interested in going back to school. Then management will make your life hell when you don't achieve your student enrollment and your daily calls and or talk time requirements. 

They also don't tell you they want you to work on Saturdays in the interview process. When you tell your director you can't work on Saturdays, they hold it against you and make your life even more miserable so miserable that you just up and quit.

review_title: A good experience in the beginning but that changed drastically.
job_title: Associate Faculty in San Diego, CA
pros: Good pay for the amount of time put in.
cons:
When I first began teaching for Ashford in 2008, it was a great experience.  I enjoyed the curriculum and I worked with several students that I really felt would make great teachers.  As time when on, I began to notice that the students admitted to Ashford University were coming in with serious academic deficits.  As an instructor for Ashford's undergraduate education program, I was horrified by the inability of these would-be/future teachers to put together coherent, grammatically correct sentences.  This started to make sense as the media began to pick up stories about Ashford's less than ethical diploma mill practices.  

About 2012, the focus of the program shifted so instructors were given "suggested" responses to provide students when giving feedback or following up on online posts.  If the scripted responses were not used and, heaven forbid, you responded authentically and individually, the instructional specialist overseeing your class would give a negative evaluation for the class.  From 2008 to 2012, I had near perfect reviews from the students and corporate.  When the canned responses became the expectation, the students weren't happy and unhappy students mean that corporate isn't happy either.  I was asked to teach a class in early 2013.  It was clear that the curriculum wasn't fully developed.  I felt it was a disservice to the students, both academically and financially.  I also received complaints from students in my class about the lack of coherence in the program which I passed along to the corporate office in San Diego.  When I was "encouraged" to use the canned responses and basically stick to the script, I informed the faculty member who had written the class that I would continue to respond in a manner that would help my students and further more, I would not be issuing any failing grades for that section since I didn't feel the students should be penalized for Ashford's lack of planning.  Shockingly, I was not asked to teach any more classes....

If you are an educator who invests deeply in your students, avoid Ashford.  You will not be allowed to truly teach.  If you're looking for an easy side job and ok with sticking to the script, then I would say go for it.

job_title: Enrollment Services Advisor in San Diego, CA
pros: Living In a great city, great benefits,  okay hours, room for promotion and growth. They have a coffee shop which is nice
cons: Pay. 39,000 to live in San Diego? Yeah that's impossible. Also management is awful. Liars cheaters scam artists. They say it's not a sales job with no quotas but it is!

job_title: Enrollment Advisor in Denver, CO
pros: Benefits, awesome co-workers, lots of paid time off around the holidays
cons: High-pressure to enroll people who are not ready to go to college.  There is a quota system--if you do not enroll enough students, they will threaten you with your job.  I've never worked a sales job where you were expected to close 35% of your leads.  They expect ten applications resulting in 4 students a month, but some months you get less than 20 leads.  Many of the leads come from folks who were job hunting and had no intention of going to college.  Many of the prospective students are homeless or on the verge of losing their homes and you are supposed to enroll them anyway.   A good number of them don't even have computers or reliable internet access.  The last thing many of these folks need is to be saddled with $30k+ in debt.  When you are worried about the basics in life, you can not focus on studying.  Many interested students never answer the phone after your initial conversation.  Management always blames the Enrollment Services Advisor.  They do not acknowledge that all of their bad press in regard to accreditation and government investigations have any impact on whether a student decides to enroll.  It's kind of a mind-f@#! in that regard.  They are constantly hiring more and more ESA's.  The turn-over is crazy.  The office is run like a middle school--complete with felt boards and lots of "good job dude!" comments coming from the managers.

review_title: Ashford University is a good place to work.
job_title: Enrollment Advisor in San Diego, CA
pros: Ashford was very student driven and promoted completion of their first course minimum to ensure sucess. Pay was good and based on performance, including 100% tution reimbursement. Fun atmosphere and good people.
cons: Very quota driven and some management were not good at training.

review_title: Do Not Believe the Positive Reviews of Ashford
job_title: Adjunct Instructor in Clinton, IA
pros: The only pro that I can report is the same for all online teaching - the fact that it is "online", which means no travel. Aside from that, there are no other positives about teaching at Ashford.
cons: Too many to list! Do yourself a favor and don't listen to any of the positive reviews of Ashford, for as another very honest person has pointed out - they are all propaganda and written by Ashford stooges.

review_title: Try the Cool-Aid, Cult of Online Admissions
job_title: Admission Counselor in Denver, CO
pros:
People do succeed by getting degrees here others not so much. 
The two week paid training was a good experience. Good place to start your life after college, and you might actually help a few people get a degree and make a better life for them. On-going training is always good, it is a transferable skill. You can make some good friends and contacts here if you put in the effort. Nice looking people overall and enroll in a Masters program while you are at it. If you are hungry and have a sweet tooth then look no further, plenty of junk food to make your day a little more tolerable. Managers will splurge by opening their $$ deep pockets and buy bagels for their team. Thanks guys/gals!
cons:
I didn't like the Cool-Aid they made us drink. It is clearly brainwashing mental warfare getting you to believe in something that is simply not the reality of Online Enrollment. Managers will force you to enroll a person with no money to their name, no computer, no car, no credit, nothing, into a $56,000 degree program and think this is ethical.
They legally say there is no sales quota, but it is painful to watch the managers tip-toe around the subject, it leads to a lot of creativity in manipulating performance of the teams. 
If you are a seasoned professional or been in the workforce for a few years, I highly recommend you continue your search elsewhere, every review on this company has truth. Please, just do your due diligence and understand fully what you are getting into when you sign your name on the bottom line. Good Luck!

job_title: Enrollment Advisor in San Diego, CA
pros: Glorified telemarketer . Nothing good about this job, everyone is miserable and if they aren't then they are using energy to pretend it's great. Co-workers and I Contemplated slashing my tire at lunch plenty of times to not have to return to work. I quit cold shoulder no job lined up - good for the soul. It's a paycheck and that's it. You meet cool people who can in turn help you find a new job. Work on Saturdays.
cons: Everything!! Managers sit at your desk while you work. Greedy CEO. Steer clear.

review_title: New Employees get Shafted, Current Employees Always on the chopping block
job_title: Enrollment Service Advisor in Denver, CO
pros:
They sell you on the fact that you can apply for full tuition reimbursement at 6 months of employment.
Good pay for a job that does not require much education. 
Great 3 week training program for the job.
cons:
Ashford talks a big game when it comes to their mission to help students obtain their education. Behind the doors is a different story. Enrollment Service Advisors are nothing but salesmen/women. As an "advisor" you are to work a database that has leads that are over 3 years old in many cases when you first start in the position.  The first few months of employment, you can expect to make up to 200 calls a day to people that have rotated through new hires databases,  to leave them messages everyday.  It is harassment in many cases.  If you are lucky enough to "Enroll" a student then you slowly start to work the ranks. Almost all of the students that are enrolled in the school are not even ready to be in college, most of them are unemployed and don't have the work ethic to get past their first few weeks of class. As an "Advisor" you are expected to "Hand hold" your students on an everyday basis. For example call them everyday to make sure that they are doing their homework; it gets old for the student and the advisor.


Forget the thought of actually starting your tuition free education as mid year reviews are issued right before the weeks leading up to enrollment as an employee.  Ashford University is a FOR PROFIT school and employees are rated solely based on numbers and how good a sales person you are.  They will give you a corrective action or terminate you for poor work performance. They will find anyway to fire employees that have been top of the table for their time spent there. This place is "At will employment" which means that they can fire you for ANY reason.  Forget having a number to call Human Resources to make a complaint or ask a question, you can not find the phone number anywhere. The employee handbook does not even have the phone number for HR.

job_title: Part-time Instructor in San Diego, CA
pros: When I first started working for Ashford in 2010 as a part-time instructor, I really enjoyed it. We had TAs to help ease the grading load (which was really helpful since they have strict deadlines on when grades are due each week) and the pay was fair. They also give you $10 a month to go toward the internet cost since they are online courses.
cons:
They got rid of TAs and started breathing down the teachers' backs about grading feedback. They basically want us to be care bears and help the students pass the classes even though many students enter my classes far behind the level they should be at (seriously some of them are at a third grade reading/writing level). They clearly are not ready to go to the next level but the grading rubrics are far too easy on the students and they really push teachers to be gentle in feedback. I consider myself to be a kind but firm instructor but I feel that I cannot really get through to some students because I have to treat them like they are first-graders. I also teach at a community college and because I am allowed to be a bit firmer with my students there, I feel that I get through to them better and they actually learn something in my class. At Ashford, they just want the students to get pushed through regardless if they are ready for the next step or not. 

Once you have hit a certain amount of courses, you stop getting a raise. They are constantly making more demands and changes that increase the workload with no extra pay. They talk to teachers as if we are students and make many passive-aggressive remarks. I will not be teaching here much longer as my frustration keeps growing with administration.

review_title: What they say in training and what they do on the floor are totally opposite!
job_title: Admissions Counselor in Denver, CO
pros: If you are just out of school and want to start your professional career, think that making between 37,000-39,000 a year is "a lot of money" and can put up with micro-management, and want to get free education to complete your degree or work on your Master's, then Ashford University could be a good fit for you.
cons: They will tell you that this is not a sales job. Don't be fooled, it is! They will tell you that you should build trust and rapport with your students on the phone, and help them to determine that they should attend Ashford University. The truth is, once you have been on the floor for more than a week you will quickly see that it is high pressure, glorified telemarketing. There is no coherance between training and the floor. You might as well get right on the phones and avoid training all toghether because your manger will even tell you to pretend like the things that you heard in training will not allow your to be a successful Admissions Councilor. They say that they would like to be the best place to work in Denver. If that is the case, they have a long way to go and hopefully will figure i out soon before they saturate the their market for potential employees. If you believe that you are an outside the box thinker, are results driven, and want to be successful, you will be pushed down and treated like dirt or you will just quit and they will not care because they hire 50-60 new employees every month. This is a revolving door company, a meat market where people are dispensible. The only thing that they care about is that you make 200-500 dials a day and try your best to prey on people and have them start school right away so that Ashford can cash in on Title IV funding. Why else would their classes start every Tuesday rather than on a semester to semester basis? This is so that their students have little to no time at all to change their mind before being obligated to pay for the classes they are taking. If you are told by a student that they can not start right away but, are willing to start classes in 10-30 days, you are told to move on and touch base with that student later when they are able to start, and move on to the next student who you can high pressure into starting this or next week. If you are lucky, the student who you were told to follow up with will not be reassigned to another councilor by then. Don't let them fool you this job is NOT customer service, it's Sales,Telemarketing, head hunting, and hardcore manipulation.

review_title: The worst experience i've ever had
job_title: Admissions Counselor in San Diego, CA
pros: the end of your shift and your pay check
cons: I cant say enough about how ridiculous this immature company is. first of all they coned me into quickly leaving my job of 3 years to come be apart of training (which is still apart of the hiring process because fyi you have to pass an assesement at the end of training in order to continue with the company)  that i supposedly would have missed come to find out there was another training class right after mine. and then lay me and 400+ people off 5 months later with out explanation other then it was based on our start date. they are a joke and lie like dogs I don't know what went wrong but they made it seem like they wanted us to be employed there for years and years and wanted to figure out why people just up and leave after 2 months of working there. ITS BECAUSE YOUR COMPANY IS AS MATURE AS A 3RD GRADE RECESS PLAY GROUND.......  DON'T GET ME WRONG their school is actual quality just  behind the scenes is the nightmare. There is no quota but people run around like there is. I've never seen people get written up so fast in my life within 5 months or less  people were written up and basically because they weren't performing, aka enrolling enough students.... but keep in mind there is no quota! the managers are immature and disrespect their team they wont teach or show you anything they expect you to know everything after training... when all training was was 3 weeks of what not to say on the phone.  they just simply don't know what they are doing where they are going or what they need. they are a terrible mess and have ruined peoples lives

review_title: Horribly managed and very much a boiler room sales environment if you're working in admissions.
job_title: University Advisor in San Diego, CA
pros: If you're on a great team with a good manager then the work environment can be fun.  I was a University Advisor (UA) and was paid pretty well but there were also Admissions Counselors (AC) who did essentially the exact same thing I did and were very often paid much less. As a UA you had some leeway in terms of when you could come and go but that was also dictated by the team you were on. We were also paid hourly which was great because we received overtime for working weekends and past eight hours in a day.
cons: You are under constant pressure to meet your quota of two students a week. That's just sales and goes with the territory but in this job it's only part of the story. Once you have a student, you have to make sure they submit all their proper forms, meet deadlines, are qualified for financial aid, etc. and many of those factors are out of your hands despite your best efforts. You can meet your number in terms of enrollments only to lose a bunch of enrollees for various reasons, subsequently causing you to fall short of your goal. In addition, there are a select few people on each team who benefit from a source of leads who are proactively looking for info about the school via the school's website. The reps who receive these leads essentially become order takers who have a much easier time hitting their number and rarely do any real prospecting and yet everyone on each team is judged according to the same standard. There is also the matter of the compliance department who monitor calls but seem to only go after low-performing admissions professionals and turn a blind eye to the folks who often play fast and loose with their verbiage but are left alone if they're meeting or exceeding their quota.

job_title: Associate Faculty (Online) in San Diego, CA
pros: While there was work, it was continuous and consistent. The salary was pretty decent for the amount of work and time commitment required when class sizes were 20-25:1. There was some support from a lead that would help you stay on top of work.
cons:
Adjunct instructors are offered assignments on 'as needed' basis, and there are no benefits attached to these positions. You get paid for running a five-week course, and that's it.
You may have as little as 3 students (for half the salary yet the same 100% commitment), or a 45-50 student load with extensive requirements. The salary is about $1,000-1,300 per 5-week course. Responding to, grading, and sending feedback to students (who mostly do not care about what you have to share with them) is time-consuming, way beyond their estimated 12 hours per week.
WHAT HAPPENED EARLIER IN 2015?
They shut down their only brick and mortar campus in Iowa earlier this year due to low enrollment, and then it looks like they offered their instructors online teaching positions. This resulted in very limited opportunities for those who were already teaching online for them, regardless of their time with the school.
WHAT HAPPENED TO MANY ONLINE INSTRUCTORS?
Emails to schedulers and other administrators were sent but never responded to. Out of the blue, a message was sent to the personal email address stating that there were no teaching opportunities and that records would stay on file for the future.
All access to email, documents, and resources was deactivated immediately.
IS THIS A LEGIT SCHOOL?
Yes, but this school has had problems with accreditation. If anyone needs this experience to count for service and/or salary increases in another education institute, please note that most will only honor fully accredited institutions.
TOO MANY POSITIONS WERE 'RESTRUCTURED'
A couple of months ago, directors were stepping down to become 'faculty,' and other positions were condensed to do more with the same salary. 

If you are looking for a reliable salary, this is not the place for it.

job_title: Anonymous in San Diego, CA
pros: usually good energy on the admissions floor unless the managers are getting yelled at by the directors and divisional vice presidents (in which case then we all suffer and hate life and are outright told to enroll anybody to get numbers needed by managers). some of us really just want to help students but are forced to talk people into start dates or we get written up.

job_title: Admissions Counselor in San Diego, CA
pros: Decent pay, Good place to get sales experience for your NEXT JOB
cons: They focus on how many students you have enrolled and do not care whether the student is a good fit or not. Your monthly quota is determined based on how many of your students actually stay in school. You could literally get written up for not meeting your quota if a student drops out and brings your "numbers down". Perhaps if they focused on getting QUALITY students who will actually stay in school and not on QUANTITY. I actually had serious concerns about a student who could not get through the application without assistance. I told me manager that I did not think that she would be a good fit and that she should probably start at a junior college first. He said, "Who cares! As long as she passes her first class you get credit for her, if she fails the rest or drops out, that not your problem." The school literally does not care about your ability to succeed. They just want your money.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: Over 5 years at this company and I can't think of any pros, when I started in 2011, things were very different, there were pros then.
cons:
Horrible working environment.  Higher ups do not bother to understand how their departments work, yet make drastic changes resulting in poor service to students and staff that hate their jobs. (Many people in my dept that had been there for years all have left in the last 2 years- management doesn't care, they replace them with people that can't do that job and end up being fired, this happened w 3 new hires in my department within a year).

Horrible benefits that get worse and more expensive every year.

NO incentives to stay.  They took away tenure increases, and merit increases last year and late in the year was able to give a small increase, but this barely covered the cost of the increase in health care.  

Constantly being lied to by directors and above.  I've never worked for a company that had so much blatant lying.  

Honestly, this for profit school is dying, there are always lay offs, enrollment will not pick up because established universities now offer online programs that  cost about the same as AU, except when they graduate their degree will help them succeed.  (Google all the lawsuits against AU.)  All these things will add to eventually becoming bankrupt and shutting its doors, just like Corinthians.  AU already closed their Iowa campus, their business offices in San Diego have been closing as well.  I bet it will be closed within 3 years, if that. 

DO NOT work here, unless this is the only job option you have.  But In-N-Out will pay pretty close to the starting salary at AU and you won't have to worry about it closing.

job_title: Admissions Counselor in San Diego, CA

job_title: Admissions Counselor/Recruiter in Julian, CA
pros: 1st time I got hired I didn't get a good feeling so I said to hell with it and kept my other job.  I had the opportunity to work here a few years later (which lasted 4 years).  Then I worked from November of last year until March of this year.   Now, the pros side is most of the time it is easy to get in and the benefits are okay.  If you work here long enough you will get the opportunity to do your job and from time to time accomplish some community work.
cons: If you work as an Admissions Advisor you have to be able to do your job and everyone else's.  Your primary job is enrolling the student which means holding their hands for 7 to 13 weeks.  After the student finishes the first class your manager could care less if you ever talk to that person again unless you're calling to ask for a referral.  See the issue is you can't treat people as human or with respect; you have to micromanage them and call them 15-20 times a day after you enroll them to ask why they haven't posted their home work.  Real fun.  At that point your student should know what's up because however long it to you for your to reach them you've already called them 5 times a day ever day (for days, weeks, months and yes, sometimes, years).  You have to make sure they get all of their FA paperwork in even though you can't receive or process any of it.  You're expected to get things accomplished in other departments that you can't call, email or walk into.  Students are told everything is good for them to start class but then are dropped for no reason or reasons that could have been prevented with communication from other departments.  Your manager/director will spend a ridiculous amount of time keeping you in training or meetings trying to figure out why you have a low talk time or why you aren't meeting your goals.  Very little positive communication from most managers/directors.  90% of the conversations start or end with how you can be or will be fired.  The mission of the company or how things are done change almost daily.  You come in early and leave late, bring them tons of money and one day someone will get a wild hair and game over... just like that.  I've had friends that enrolled +500 students a year get walked out over BS. 500 x 750 (military students) times 10 (number of classes each student can take per year) ... do the math.
